http://www.biop.ox.ac.uk/coot/ }} The program '''Coot''' ('''Crystallographic Object-Oriented Toolkit'''){{cite journal|author1=P. Emsley|author2=B. Lohkamp|author3=W.G. Scott|author4=Cowtan|date=2010|title=''Features and Development of Coot''|journal=Acta Crystallographica|volume=D66|pages=486–501|url=http://journals.iucr.org/d/issues/2010/04/00/ba5144/index.html|doi=10.1107/s0907444910007493|pmc=2852313}}{{cite journal|author1=P. Emsley|author2=K. Cowtan |date=2004|title=''Coot: model-building tools for molecular graphics''|journal=Acta Crystallographica|volume=D60|pages=2126–2132|url=http://scripts.iucr.org/cgi-bin/paper?S0907444904019158|doi=10.1107/s0907444904019158}} is used to display and manipulate atomic models of macromolecules, typically of proteins or nucleic acids, using [[3D computer graphics]]. It is primarily focused on building and validation of atomic models into three-dimensional [[Resolution (electron density)|electron density]] maps obtained by [[X-ray crystallography]] methods, although it has also been applied to data from [[electron microscopy]]. ==Overview== Coot displays electron density maps and atomic models and allows model manipulations such as idealization, real space refinement, manual rotation/translation, rigid-body fitting, ligand search, solvation, mutations, rotamers, and [[Ramachandran plot|Ramachandran idealization]]. The software is designed to be easy-to-learn for novice users, achieved by ensuring that tools for common tasks are 'discoverable' through familiar user interface elements (menus and toolbars), or by intuitive behaviour (mouse controls). Recent developments have enhanced the usability of the software for expert users, with customisable key bindings, extensions, and an extensive scripting interface. Coot is [[free software]], distributed under the GNU GPL. It is available from the Coot web site{{cite web|url=http://www2.mrc-lmb.cam.ac.uk/Personal/pemsley/coot/ |title=Coot |website=Mrc-lmb.cam.ac.uk |date= |accessdate=2017-02-27}} originally at the [[University of York]], and now at the [[Laboratory of Molecular Biology|MRC Laboratory of Molecular Biology]]. Pre-compiled binaries are also available for Linux and Windows from the web page and [[Collaborative Computational Project Number 4|CCP4]], and for Mac OS X through [[Fink]] and CCP4. Additional support is available through the Coot wiki and an active COOT mailing list.{{cite web|url=http://strucbio.biologie.uni-konstanz.de/ccp4wiki/index.php/Coot |title=Coot - CCP4 wiki |website=Strucbio.biologie.uni-konstanz.de |date= |accessdate=2017-02-27}}{{cite web|url=https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk/cgi-bin/webadmin?A0=coot |title=Coot List At Www.Jiscmail.Ac.Uk |publisher=JISCMail |date= |accessdate=2017-02-27}} The primary author is [[Paul Emsley (crystallographer)|Paul Emsley]] ([[Laboratory of Molecular Biology|MRC-LMB at Cambridge]]). Other contributors include Kevin Cowtan, Bernhard Lohkamp and Stuart McNicholas ([[University of York]]), William Scott ([[University of California at Santa Cruz]]), and Eugene Krissinel ([[Daresbury Laboratory]]). ==Features== Coot can be used to read files containing 3D atomic coordinate models of macromolecular structures in a number of formats, including [[Protein Data Bank (file format)|pdb]], [[mmcif]], and Shelx files. The model may then be rotated in 3D and viewed from any viewpoint. The atomic model is represented by default using a stick-model, with vectors representing chemical bonds. The two halves of each bond are coloured according to the element of the atom at that end of the bond, allowing chemical structure and identity to be visualised in a manner familiar to most chemists. Coot can also display electron density, which is the result of structure determination experiments such as X-ray crystallography and EM reconstruction. The density is contoured using a 3D-mesh. The contour level controlled using the mouse wheel for easy manipulation - this provides a simple way for the user to get an idea of the 3D electron density profile without the visual clutter of multiple contour levels. Electron density may be read into the program from [[CCP4 (file format)|ccp4]] or [[Crystallography and NMR system|cns]] map formats, though it is more common to calculate an electron density map directly from the X-ray diffraction data, read from an mtz, hkl, fcf or mmcif file. Coot provides extensive features for model building and refinement (i.e. adjusting the model to better fit the electron density), and for validation (i.e. checking that the atomic model agrees with the experimentally derived electron density and makes chemical sense). The most important of these tools is the real space refinement engine, which will optimize the fit of a section of atomic model to the electron density in real time, with graphical feedback. The user may also intervene in this process, dragging the atoms into the right places if the initial model is too far away from the corresponding electron density. ===Model building tools=== [[Image:Coot-crystallography-software-realspacerefine.png|right|thumb|150px|Coot Real Space Refinement]] [[Image:Coot-crystallography-software-addresidue.png|right|thumb|150px|Coot Add Terminal Residue]] Tools for general model building: * ''C-alpha baton mode'' - trace the main chain of a protein by placing correctly spaced alpha-carbon atoms. * ''Ca Zone -> Mainchain'' - convert an initial trace of the alpha-carbon atoms to a full main-chain trace. * ''Place helix here'' - fit a sequence of amino acids in [[alpha helix]] conformation into density. * ''Place strand here'' - fit a sequence of amino acids in [[beta strand]] conformation into density. * ''Ideal DNA/RNA'' - build an ideal DNA or RNA fragment. * ''Find ligands'' - find and fit a model to any small molecule which may be bound to the macromolecule. Tools for moving existing atoms: * ''Real space refine zone'' - optimize the fit of the model to the electron density, while preserving stereochemistry. * ''Regularize zone'' - optimize stereochemistry. * ''Rigid body fit zone'' - optimize the fit of a rigid body to the electron density. * ''Rotate/translate zone'' - manually position a rigid body. * ''Rotamer tools (auto fit rotamer, manual rotamer, mutate and autofit, simple mutate)'' * ''Torsion editing (edit chi angles, edit main chain torsions, general torsions)'' * ''Other protein tools (flip peptide, flip sidechain, cis <-> trans)'' Tools for adding atoms to the model: * ''Find waters'' - add ordered solvent molecules to the model * ''Add terminal residue'' - extend a protein or nucleotide chain * ''Add alternate conformation'' * ''Place atom at pointer'' ===Validation tools=== [[Image:Coot-crystallography-software-ramachandran.png|right|thumb|150px|Coot Ramachandran plot validation tool]] [[Image:Coot-crystallography-software-densityfit.png|right|thumb|150px|Coot density fit validation tool]] In macromolecular crystallography, the observed data is often weak and the observation-to-parameter ratio near 1. As a result, it is possible to build an incorrect atomic model into the electron density in some cases. To avoid this, careful validation is required. Coot provides a range of validation tools, listed below. Having built an initial model, it is usual to check all of these and reconsider any parts of the model which are highlighted as problematic before deposition of the atomic coordinates with a public database. * ''[[Ramachandran plot]]'' - validate the [[torsion angle]]s of a protein chain. * ''[[Gerard Kleywegt|Kleywegt]] plot'' - examine differences between the torsions of NCS-related chains. * ''Incorrect chiral volumes'' - check for chiral centres with the wrong handedness. * ''Unmodelled blobs'' - check for electron density not accounted for by existing atoms. * ''[[Difference density map|Difference map]] peaks'' - check for large differences between observed and calculated density. * ''Check/Delete waters'' - check for water molecules which do not fit the density. * ''Check waters by difference map variance'' * ''Geometry analysis'' - check for improbable bond lengths, angles, etc. * ''[[Peptide bond|Peptide]] omega analysis'' - check for non-planar peptide bonds. * ''Temperature factor variance analysis'' - * ''GLN and ASN B-factor outliers'' - * ''[[Rotamer]] analysis'' - check for unusual protein side-chain conformations. * ''Density fit analysis'' - identify parts of the model which don't fit the density. * ''Probe clashes'' - check for Hydrogen atoms with inappropriate environments (using Molprobity). * ''NCS differences'' - check for general differences between NCS related chains. * ''Pukka puckers'' - check for unusual DNA/RNA conformations. ==Program architecture== [[Image:Coot-crystallography-software-structure.png|right|thumb|300px|Coot structure]] Coot is built upon a number of libraries. Crystallographic tools include the Clipper library{{cite web|url=http://www.ysbl.york.ac.uk/~cowtan/clipper/clipper.html |title=Dr Kevin Cowtan - About staff, The University of York |website=Ysbl.york.ac.uk |date=2014-10-23 |accessdate=2017-02-27}} for manipulating electron density and providing crystallographic algorithms, and the MMDB[https://web.archive.org/web/20020610085144/http://www.ebi.ac.uk/~keb/cldoc/ ] for the manipulation of atomic models. Other dependencies include [[FFTW]], and the [[GNU Scientific Library]]. Much of the program's functionality is available through a scripting interface, which provides access from both the Python and Guile scripting languages. ==Relation to CCP4mg== The CCP4mg molecular graphics software{{cite journal|author=L. Potterton, S. McNicholas, E. Krissinel, J. Gruber, K. Cowtan, P. Emsley, G. N. Murshudov, S. Cohen, A. Perrakis and M. Noble |date=2004|title=''Developments in the CCP4 molecular-graphics project''|journal=Acta Crystallogr|volume=D60|pages=2288-2294|url=http://scripts.iucr.org/cgi-bin/paper?ba5074}}[https://web.archive.org/web/20050610031449/http://www.ysbl.york.ac.uk/~ccp4mg/ ] from [[Collaborative Computational Project Number 4]] is a related project with which Coot shares some code. The projects are focused on slightly different problems, with CCP4mg dealing with presentation graphics and movies, whereas Coot deals with model building and validation. ==Impact in the crystallographic computing community== The software has gained considerable popularity over the past 5 years, overtaking widely used packages such as 'O',{{cite web|url=http://xray.bmc.uu.se/~alwyn/ |title=Home Page of Alwyn Jones |website=Xray.bmc.uu.se |accessdate=2017-02-27}} XtalView,{{cite web|url=http://www.sdsc.edu/CCMS/Packages/XTALVIEW/xtalview.html |title=CCMS Software - XtalView |website=Sdsc.edu |date=2006-08-09 |accessdate=2017-02-27}} and Turbo Frodo.{{cite web|url=http://www.csb.yale.edu/userguides/graphics/turbofrodo/turbo_descrip.html |title=Turbo Frodo Description |website=Csb.yale.edu |date=1999-03-26 |accessdate=2017-02-27}} The primary publication has been cited in over 10,000 independent scientific papers since 2004.{{cite web|url=https://scholar.google.co.uk/scholar?q=Coot+model+building+tools+for+molecular+graphics&btnG=&hl=en&as_sdt=0%2C5 |title=Coot model building tools for molecular graphics - Google Scholar |website=Scholar.google.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2017-02-27}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www2.mrc-lmb.cam.ac.uk/Personal/pemsley/coot/ Coot website] [[Category:Crystallography software]] [[Category:Molecular modelling software]] [[Category:Bioinformatics software]] [[Category:Free science software]] [[Category:Free chemistry software]] [[Category:Science software that uses GTK+]] [[Category:Science software for Linux]]

The '''Critical Assessment of Functional Annotation''' (CAFA) is an experiment designed to provide a large-scale assessment of computational methods dedicated to [[Protein function prediction|predicting protein function]].{{cite journal|last=Predrag|first=Radivojac|title=A large-scale evaluation of computational protein function prediction|journal=Nature Methods|year=2013|volume=10|pages=221–227|doi=10.1038/nmeth.2340|pmid=23353650|issue=3|pmc=3584181|display-authors=etal|url=https://archive-ouverte.unige.ch/unige:33780/ATTACHMENT01}} Different [[algorithms]] are evaluated by their ability to predict the [[Gene Ontology]] (GO) terms in the categories of [[Gene ontology#GO terms and ontology|Molecular Function]], [[Gene ontology#GO terms and ontology|Biological Process]], and [[Gene ontology#GO terms and ontology|Cellular Component]]. The experiment consists of two tracks: (i) the [[eukaryotic]] track, (ii) the [[prokaryotic]] track. In each track, a set of targets is provided by the organizers. Participants are expected to submit their predictions by the submission deadline, after which they are assessed according to a set of specific metrics. ==Motivation== The [[genome]] of an organism may consist of hundreds to tens of thousands of [[genes]], which encode for hundreds of thousands of different [[protein]] sequences. Due to the relatively low cost of [[genome sequencing]], determining gene and protein sequences is fast and inexpensive. Thousands of species have been sequenced so far, yet many of the proteins are not well characterized.{{cite journal|last=Bernal|first=Axel|author2=Uy Ear |author3=Nikos Kyrpides |title=Genomes OnLine Database (GOLD): a monitor of genome projects world-wide|journal=Nucleic Acids Research|year=2001|volume=29 | issue = 1|pages=126–127|doi=10.1093/nar/29.1.126}} The process of experimentally determining the role of a protein in the cell, is an expensive and time consuming task. Further, even when functional [[assays]] are performed they are unlikely to provide complete insight into protein function. Therefore it has become important to use computational tools in order to functionally annotate proteins. There are several computational methods of protein function prediction that can infer protein function using a variety of biological and evolutionary data, but there is significant room for improvement. Accurate prediction of protein function can have longstanding implications on biomedical and pharmaceutical research. The CAFA experiment is designed to provide unbiased assessment of computational methods, to stimulate research in computational function prediction, and provide insights into the overall state-of-the-art in function prediction. ==Organization== The experiment consists of three phases: # ''Prediction phase'': ~4 months Organizers provide protein sequences with unknown or incomplete function to community and set the deadline for the submission of predictions # ''Target accumulation'': 6–12 months After all predictions are stored and the experiment enters a waiting period in which protein functions are expected to accumulate in public databases # ''Analysis Phase'': 1 month Predictors are ranked according to their performance. The results are publicly shared in scientific meetings and published after [[peer review]]. ==History== The CAFA experiment is conducted by the Automated Function Prediction (AFP) Special Interest Group (AFP/SIG). An AFP/SIG meeting has been held alongside the [[Intelligent Systems for Molecular Biology]] conference in 2005, 2006, 2008, 2011, and 2012.{{cite journal|last=Friedberg|first=Iddo|author2=Martin Jambon |author3=Adam Godzik |title=New avenues in protein function prediction|journal=Protein Science|date=June 2006|volume=15|issue=6|pages=1527–1529|doi=10.1110/ps.062158406|pmid=16731984|pmc=2242544}}{{cite journal|last=Rodrigues|first=Ana |author2=Barry Grant |author3=Adam Godzik |author4=Iddo Friedberg|title=The 2006 Automated Function Prediction Meeting|journal=Bioinformatics|year=2007|volume=8|issue=Suppl 4|pages=S1–4 |doi=10.1186/1471-2105-8-s4-s1 |pmid=17570143 |pmc=1892079}}{{cite journal|last=Gillis|first=Jesse|author2=Paul Pavlidis|title=Characterizing the state of the art in the computational assignment of gene function: lessons from the first critical assessment of functional annotation (CAFA)|journal=BMC Bioinformatics|date=April 2013|volume=14|issue=Suppl 3|page=S15|doi=10.1186/1471-2105-14-s3-s15}} The first CAFA experiment was organized between fall 2010 and spring 2012. The organizers provided 48,000 sequences for the community with the task to prediction Gene Ontology annotations for each of these sequences. Of those 48,000 proteins, 866 were experimentally annotated during target accumulation phase. The results showed that current function prediction algorithms perform significantly better than a simple domain assignment or a straightforward use of [[BLAST]] package. However, they also revealed that accurate prediction of a protein's biological function is still an open and challenging problem. ===CAFA 2010-2012=== The first CAFA experiment was organized between fall 2010 and spring 2012. The organizers provided 48,000 sequences for the community with the task to prediction Gene Ontology annotations for each of these sequences. Of those 48,000 proteins, 866 were experimentally annotated during target accumulation phase. The results showed that current function prediction algorithms perform significantly better than a simple domain assignment or a straightforward use of [[BLAST]] package. However, they also revealed that accurate prediction of a protein's biological function is still an open and challenging problem. === CAFA 2013-2014 === The second CAFA experiment kicked off in fall 2013. Starting in August, interested parties could download more than 100,000 target sequences in 27 species. Registered teams are challenged to annotate the sequences with Gene Ontology terms, with an additional challenge to annotate human sequences with [[Human Phenotype Ontology]] terms. The submission deadline was January 15, 2014. The assessment of predictions will take place in June 2014. ==See also== [[CASP]]: [[CASP|Critical Assessment of protein Structure Prediction]]
[[Critical Assessment of Prediction of Interactions|CAPRI]]: [[Critical Assessment of Prediction of Interactions]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://biofunctionprediction.org/ Automated Function Prediction Special Interest Group] - CAFA Challenge participation information [[Category:Bioinformatics]]

{{About|fall protection in the workplace|prevention of domestic falls in older adults|Fall prevention}} {{refimprove|date=March 2016}} [[File:Fall protection allows his men to go home at the end of the day.webm|thumb|A video on the value of fall protection measures]] '''Fall protection''' is the use of controls designed to protect personnel from [[Falling (accident)|falling]] or in the event they do fall, to stop them without causing severe injury. Typically, fall protection is implemented when working at height, but may be relevant when working near any edge, such as near a pit or hole, or performing work on a steep surface.
There are four generally accepted categories of fall protection: fall elimination, fall prevention, [[fall arrest]] and administrative controls.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Ellis|first1=J. Nigel|title=Introduction to fall protection|date=2011|publisher=[[American Society of Safety Engineers]]|isbn=9781885581587|page=28|edition=4th}}<!--|accessdate=24 March 2016--></ref> According to the US Department of Labor, falls account for 8% of all work-related trauma injuries leading to death.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Bickrest|first1=Ed|title=Fall Protection: Failure is Not an Option|url=http://ehstoday.com/ppe/fall-protection/falls-remain-occupational-hazard-0309|website=EHS Today|accessdate=24 March 2016}}</ref> Federal statutes, standards and regulations in the United States pertaining to the requirements for employers to provide fall protection are administered by [[Occupational Safety and Health Administration|OSHA]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Duty to have fall protection. 1926.501|url=https://www.osha.gov/pls/oshaweb/owadisp.show_document?p_table=STANDARDS&p_id=10757|website=Occupational Safety & Health Administration|publisher=United States Dept. of Labor|accessdate=30 March 2016}}</ref>
== Falls in the workplace == Falls from elevations were the fourth leading cause of workplace death from 1980 through 1994, with an average of 540 deaths per year accounting for 10% of all occupational fatalities.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cdc.gov/niosh/docs/2000-116/|title=Worker Deaths by Falls: A Summary of Surveillance Findings and Investigative Case Reports|last=|first=|date=|website=U.S. [[National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health]]|page=xi|language=en-us|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-05-04}}</ref>
Falls are a concern for oil and gas workers, many of whom must work high on a [[derrick]]. A study of falls over the period 2005–2014 found that in 86% of fatal falls studied, fall protection was required by regulation, but it was not used, was used improperly, or the equipment failed. Many of the fatalities were because, although the workers were wearing harnesses, they neglected to attach them to an anchor point.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Mason|first=Krystal L.|last2=Retzer|first2=Kyla D.|last3=Hill|first3=Ryan|last4=Lincoln|first4=Jennifer M.|date=2017-01-01|title=Occupational Fatalities Resulting from Falls in the Oil and Gas Extraction Industry, United States, 2005–2014|url=https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/66/wr/mm6616a2.htm|journal=[[Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report]]|language=en-us|volume=66|issue=16|pages=417–421|doi=10.15585/mmwr.mm6616a2|issn=0149-2195}}</ref>
== Types of fall protection == In most work-at-height environments, multiple fall protection measures are used concurrently.
=== Fall elimination === Fall [[Hazard elimination|elimination]] is often the preferred way of providing fall protection. This entails finding ways of completing tasks without working at heights.
=== Fall prevention === {{main|Fall prevention}} * Fall guarding is the use of guard rails or other barricades to prevent a person from falling. These barricades are placed near an edge where a fall-hazard can occur, or to surround a weak surface (such as a skylight on a roof) which may break when stepped on. * Fall restraint is a class of [[personal protective equipment]] to prevent persons who are in a fall hazard area from falling, e.g., fall restraint lanyards. Typically, fall restraint will physically prevent a worker from approaching an edge.
=== Fall arrest === {{main article|Fall arrest}} Fall arrest is the form of fall protection that stops a person who has fallen.
=== Administrative controls === [[Administrative controls]] are used along with other measures, but they do not physically prevent a worker from going over an edge.<ref>{{cite web|title=Fall Protection|url=https://www.osha.gov/pls/oshaweb/owadisp.show_document?p_table=STANDARDS&p_id=10758|website=United States Department of Labor|publisher=Occupational Safety and Health Administration|accessdate=24 March 2016}}</ref> Examples of administrative controls include placing a safety observer or warning line near an edge, or enforcing a safety policy which trains workers and requires them to adhere to other fall protection measures, or prohibiting any un-restrained worker from approaching an edge.
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{italic title}} {{Taxobox | name = Fibrobacteres | domain = [[Bacteria]] | phylum = [[Fibrobacteres]] | classis = [[Fibrobacteria]] | ordo = [[Fibrobacterales]] | familia = [[Fibrobacteraceae]] | genus = ''[[Fibrobacter]]'' | species = ''F. succinogenes'' | binomial = ''Fibrobacter succinogenes'' | binomial_authority = (Hungate, 1950) Montgomery et al., 1988 | subdivision_ranks = Subspecies | subdivision = * ''[[Fibrobacter succinogenes elongatus|F. s. elongatus]]'' <small>Montgomery et al. 1988</small> * ''[[Fibrobacter succinogenes succinogenes|F. s. succinogenes]]'' <small>(Hungate 1950) Montgomery et al. 1988</small> | synonyms = * ''Bacteroides succinogenes'' Hungate, 1950 * ''Ruminobacter succinogenes'' (Hungate, 1950) Prevot, 1966 }} '''''Fibrobacter succinogenes''''' is a cellulolytic [[bacterium]] species in the genus ''[[Fibrobacter]]''. It is present in the [[rumen]] of cattle. Beta glucans are its substrate of choice in the rumen and its products after digestion include formate, acetate and succinate. Fibrobacter succinogenes forms characteristic extensive grooves in [[crystal]]line [[cellulose]], and is also rather readily detached from its substrate during sample preparation.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/0377-8401(95)00830-6 |title=Digestibility of cotton lint fiber and whole oilseeds by ruminal microorganisms |journal=Animal Feed Science and Technology |volume=56 |issue=3–4 |pages=231–42 |year=1995 |last1=Palmquist |first1=D.L. }}</ref>
== Close relationship of ''Fibrobacter succinogenes'' to'' Bacteroidetes'' and ''Chlorobi'' phyla == Phylogenetic studies based RpoC and Gyrase B protein sequences, indicate that ''Fibrobacter succinogenes'' is closely related to the species from the phyla ''Bacteroidetes'' and ''Chlorobi''.<ref name="Gupta">{{cite journal | vauthors = Gupta RS | title = The phylogeny and signature sequences characteristics of Fibrobacteres, Chlorobi, and Bacteroidetes | journal = Critical Reviews in Microbiology | volume = 30 | issue = 2 | pages = 123–43 | year = 2008 | pmid = 15239383 | doi = 10.1080/10408410490435133 }}</ref> ''Fibrobacter succinogenes'' and the species from these two other phyla also branch in the same position based upon conserved signature indels in a number of important proteins.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Griffiths E, Gupta RS | title = The use of signature sequences in different proteins to determine the relative branching order of bacterial divisions: evidence that Fibrobacter diverged at a similar time to Chlamydia and the Cytophaga-Flavobacterium-Bacteroides division | journal = Microbiology | volume = 147 | issue = Pt 9 | pages = 2611–22 | date = September 2001 | pmid = 11535801 | doi = 10.1099/00221287-147-9-2611 }}</ref> Lastly and most importantly, comparative genomic studies have identified two conserved signature indels (a 5-7 amino acid insert in the RpoC protein and a 13-16 amino acid insertion in [[serine hydroxymethyltransferase]]) and one signature protein (PG00081) that are uniquely shared by ''Fibrobacter succinogenes'' and all of the species from ''Bacteroidetes'' and ''Chlorobi'' phyla.<ref name="GuptaB">{{cite journal | vauthors = Gupta RS, Lorenzini E | title = Phylogeny and molecular signatures (conserved proteins and indels) that are specific for the Bacteroidetes and Chlorobi species | journal = BMC Evolutionary Biology | volume = 7 | pages = 71 | date = May 2007 | pmid = 17488508 | pmc = 1887533 | doi = 10.1186/1471-2148-7-71 }}</ref> All of these results provide compelling evidence that ''Fibrobacter succinogenes'' shared a common ancestor with ''Bacteroidetes'' and ''Chlorobi'' species exclusive of all other bacteria, and these species should be recognized as part of a single [[FCB group|“FCB”superphylum]].<ref name="Gupta"/><ref name="GuptaB" />
== See also == * [[Fssl]], a [[List of restriction enzyme cutting sites: E–F|restriction enzyme]] found in ''F. succinogenes'' * [[List of methanogens in digestive tract of ruminants]]

{{Hatnote|This article outlines the historical development of the laws describing ideal gases. For a detailed description of the ideal gas laws and their further development, see [[ideal gas law]].}}
The '''gas laws''' were developed at the end of the 18th century, when scientists began to realize that relationships between [[pressure]], [[volume]] and [[temperature]] of a sample of [[gas]] could be obtained which would hold to approximation for all gases. Gases behave in a similar way over a wide variety of conditions because they all have [[molecule]]s which are widely spaced, and the [[equation of state]] for an [[ideal gas]] is derived from [[kinetic theory of gases|kinetic theory]]. The earlier gas laws are now considered as special cases of the [[ideal gas equation]], with one or more variables held constant.
==Boyle's Laws== {{Main|Boyle's law}} In 1662 Robert Boyle studied the relationship between volume and pressure of a gas of fixed amount at constant temperature. He observed that volume of a given mass of a gas is inversely proportional to its pressure at a constant temperature. Boyle's law, published in 1662, states that, at constant temperature, the product of the pressure and volume of a given mass of an [[ideal gas]] in a closed system is always constant. It can be verified experimentally using a pressure gauge and a variable volume container. It can also be derived from the kinetic theory of gases: if a container, with a fixed number of molecules inside, is reduced in volume, more molecules will strike a given area of the sides of the container per unit time, causing a greater pressure.
A statement of Boyle's law is as follows:
:The volume of a given mass of a gas is inversely related to pressure when the temperature is constant.
The concept can be represented with these formulae:
:<math>V \propto \frac{1}{P}</math>, meaning "Volume is directly proportional to 1 divided by Pressure", or :<math>P \propto \frac{1}{V}</math>, meaning "Pressure is directly proportional to 1 divided by Volume", or :<math>PV=k_1</math>, or :<math>P_1 V_1=P_2 V_2\,</math>
:where ''P'' is the pressure, and ''V'' is the volume of a gas, and ''k''<sub>1</sub> is the constant in this equation (and is not the same as the proportionality constants in the other equations in this article).
==Charles's law== {{Main|Charles's law}} Charles's law, or the law of volumes, was found in 1787 by Jacques Charles. It states that, for a given mass of an ideal gas at constant pressure, the volume is directly proportional to its [[absolute temperature]], assuming in a closed system.
The statement of Charles's law is as follows: the volume (V) of a given mass of a gas, at constant pressure (P), is directly proportional to its temperature (T). As a mathematical equation, Charles's law is written as either: :<math>V \propto T\,</math>, or :<math>V/T=k_2</math>, or :<math>V_1/T_1=V_2/T_2</math>,
where ''V'' is the volume of a gas, ''T'' is the absolute temperature and ''k''<sub>2</sub> is a proportionality constant (which is not the same as the proportionality constants in the other equations in this article).
==Gay-Lussac's law== {{Main|Gay-Lussac's law}} Gay-Lussac's law, Amontons' law or the pressure law was found by [[Joseph Louis Gay-Lussac]] in 1809. It states that, for a given mass and constant volume of an ideal gas, the pressure exerted on the sides of its container is directly proportional to its [[absolute temperature]].
As a mathematical equation, Gay-Lussac's law is written as either:
:<math>P \propto T\,</math>, or
:<math>P/T=k</math>, or K=P divided by T :<math>P_1/T_1=P_2/T_2</math>,
:where ''P'' is the pressure, ''T'' is the absolute temperature, and ''k'' is another proportionality constant.
==Avogadro's law== {{Main|Avogadro's law}}
Avogadro's law states that the volume occupied by an ideal gas is directly proportional to the number of molecules of the gas present in the container. This gives rise to the [[molar volume]] of a gas, which at [[Standard conditions for temperature and pressure|STP]] (273.15 K, 1 atm) is about 22.4 L. The relation is given by
:<math>\frac{V_1}{n_1}=\frac{V_2}{n_2} \,</math>
:where ''n'' is equal to the number of molecules of gas (or the number of moles of gas).
==Combined and ideal gas laws== {{main|Ideal gas law}} The [[Combined gas law]] or General Gas Equation is obtained by combining Boyle's Law, Charles's law, and Gay-Lussac's Law. It shows the relationship between the pressure, volume, and temperature for a fixed mass (quantity) of gas:
:<math>pV = k_5T \,</math>
This can also be written as:
:<math> \qquad \frac {p_1V_1}{T_1}= \frac {p_2V_2}{T_2} </math>
With the addition of [[Avogadro's law]], the [[combined gas law]] develops into the [[ideal gas law]]:
:<math>pV = nRT \,</math>
:where
:''p'' is pressure :''V'' is volume :''n'' is the number of moles :''R'' is the universal gas constant :''T'' is temperature (K)
:where the proportionality constant, now named R, is the [[universal gas constant]] with a value of 8.3144598 (kPa∙L)/(mol∙K). An equivalent formulation of this law is:
:<math>pV = kNT \,</math>
:where
:''p'' is the pressure :''V'' is the volume :''N'' is the number of gas molecules :''k'' is the [[Boltzmann constant]] (1.381×10<sup>−23 </sup>J·K<sup>−1</sup> in SI units) :''T'' is the temperature (K)
These equations are exact only for an [[ideal gas]], which neglects various intermolecular effects (see [[real gas]]). However, the ideal gas law is a good approximation for most gases under moderate pressure and temperature.
This law has the following important consequences: # If temperature and pressure are kept constant, then the volume of the gas is directly proportional to the number of molecules of gas. # If the temperature and volume remain constant, then the pressure of the gas changes is directly proportional to the number of molecules of gas present. # If the number of gas molecules and the temperature remain constant, then the pressure is inversely proportional to the volume. # If the temperature changes and the number of gas molecules are kept constant, then either pressure or volume (or both) will change in direct proportion to the temperature.
==Other gas laws== * [[Graham's law]] states that the rate at which gas molecules [[diffusion|diffuse]] is inversely proportional to the square root of its density at constant temperature. Combined with Avogadro's law (i.e. since equal volumes have equal number of molecules) this is the same as being inversely proportional to the root of the molecular weight. * [[Dalton's law]] of [[partial pressures]] states that the pressure of a mixture of gases simply is the sum of the [[partial pressures]] of the individual components. Dalton's law is as follows:
:<math> P_{\rm total} = P_1 + P_2 + P_3 + ... + P_n \equiv \sum_{i=1}^n P_i \,</math>,
or
:<math> P_\mathrm{total} = P_\mathrm{gas} + P_\mathrm{H_2 O} \,</math>
:where ''P''<sub>Total</sub> is the total pressure of the atmosphere, :''P''<sub>Gas</sub> is the pressure of the gas mixture in the atmosphere, :and ''P''<sub>H<sub>2</sub>O</sub> is the water pressure at that temperature.
* [[Amagat's law]] of [[Partial gas volume|partial volume]] states that the volume of a mixture of gases (or the volume of the container) simply is the sum of the partial volumes of the individual components. Amagat's law is as follows:
:<math> V_{\rm total} = V_1 + V_2 + V_3 + ... + V_n \equiv \sum_{i=1}^n V_i \,</math>,
:where ''V''<sub>Total</sub> is the total volume of the gas mixture, or the volume of the container, :''V''<sub>i</sub> is the partial volume of the gas in the gas mixture at that pressure and that temperature.
* [[Henry's law]] states that: :''At constant temperature, the amount of a given gas dissolved in a given type and volume of liquid is directly proportional to the [[partial pressure]] of that gas in equilibrium with that liquid.''
:<math> p = k_{\rm H}\, c</math>
* [[Real gas law]], formulated by [[Johannes Diderik van der Waals]] (1873).
==References== *{{Cite book |author1=Castka, Joseph F. |author2=Metcalfe, H. Clark |author3=Davis, Raymond E. |author4=Williams, John E. | title=Modern Chemistry | publisher=Holt, Rinehart and Winston | year=2002 | isbn=0-03-056537-5}} *{{Cite book | author=Guch, Ian | title=The Complete Idiot's Guide to Chemistry | publisher=Alpha, Penguin Group Inc. | year=2003 | isbn=1-59257-101-8}} *{{Cite book | author=Zumdahl, Steven S | title=Chemical Principles | publisher=Houghton Mifflin Company | year=1998 | isbn=0-395-83995-5}}

{{Underlinked|date=January 2014}}
In [[development studies]], the concept of a [[value chain]] has been used to analyse [[international trade]] in global value chains which comprises “the full range of activities that are required to bring a product from its conception, through its design, its sourced raw materials and intermediate inputs, its marketing, its distribution and its support to the final consumer”.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://globalvaluechains.org/concept-tools|title=Concept & Tools - Global Value Chains|website=Globalvaluechains.org|accessdate=19 April 2018}}</ref> Specifically, when activities must be coordinated across geographies, the term '''global value chain''' ('''GVC''') is used in the development literature. Simply put, the global value chain includes all of the people and activities involved in the production of a good or service and its global level supply, distribution and post sales activities (also known as the [[supply chain]]). GVC is similar to [[Value_chain#Industry-level|Industry Level Value Chain]] but encompasses operations at the global level.
== In development == The first references to the GVC concept date from the mid-1990s and were enthusiastic about the upgrading prospects for [[Developing country|developing countries]] that joined them. In his early work based on research on East Asian garment firms, the pioneer in value chain analysis, [[Gary Gereffi]], describes a process of almost ‘natural’ learning and upgrading for the firms that joined GVCs.<ref>Gereffi, G., (1994). The Organisation of Buyer-Driven Global Commodity Chains: How US Retailers Shape Overseas Production Networks. In G. Gereffi, and M. Korzeniewicz (Eds), Commodity Chains and Global Capitalism. Westport, CT: Praeger.</ref> This echoed the ‘export-led’ discourse of the [[World Bank]] in the ‘[[East Asian Miracle]]’ report based on the East Asian ‘[[Four Asian Tigers|Tigers]]’ success.
This encouraged the World Bank and other leading institutions to encourage developing firms to develop their indigenous capabilities through a process of upgrading technical capabilities to meet global standards with leading multinational enterprises ([[Multinational corporation|MNE]]) playing a key role in helping local firms through transfer of new technology, skills and knowledge.
Wider adoption of [[open source hardware]] technology used for [[digital fabrication]] such as [[3D printers]] like the [[RepRap]] has the potential to partially reverse the trend towards global specialization of production systems into elements that may be geographically dispersed and closer to the end users (localization) and thus disrupt global value chains.<ref> André O. Laplume, Bent Petersen, Joshua M. Pearce, [https://www.academia.edu/27224636/Global_Value_Chains_from_a_3D_Printing_Perspective Global value chains from a 3D printing perspective], ''Journal of International Business Studies'' 47(5), 595–609 (2016). doi:10.1057/jibs.2015.47 </ref>
GVC analysis views “upgrading” as a continuum starting with “process upgrading” (e.g. a producer adopts better technology to improve efficiency), then moves on to “product upgrading” where the quality or functionality of the product is upgraded by using higher quality material or a better quality management system ([[Quality management system|QMS]]), and then on to “functional upgrading” in which the firm begins to design its own product and develops marketing and branding capabilities and begins to supply to end markets/customers directly - often by targeting geographies or customers which are not served by its existing multinational clients). Subsequently, the process of upgrading might also cover inter-sectoral upgrading.<ref name="Humphrey and Schmitz (2004)">Humphrey, J., and H. Schmitz. 2004. "Chain Governance and Upgrading: Taking Stock". in ''Local Enterprises in the Global Economy'', edited by H. Schmitz, 349–82. Cheltenham: Edward Elgar.</ref>
This upgrading process in GVCs has been challenged by other researchers – some of whom argue that insertion in global value chains does not always lead to upgrading. Some authors<ref>Humphrey, J. and Schmitz, H. (2000). Governance and Upgrading: Linking Industrial Cluster and Global Value Chain. IDS Working Paper 120, Institute of Development Studies, University of Sussex, Brighton.</ref> argue that the expected upgrading process might not hold for all types of upgrading. Specifically they argue upgrading into design, marketing and branding might be hindered by exporting under certain conditions because MNEs have no interest in transferring these core skills to their suppliers thus preventing them from accessing global markets (except as a supplier) for first world customer.
=== Current research on governance and its impact from a development perspective === There are motivations behind renewed interest in global value chains and the opportunities that they may present for countries in [[South Asia]]. A 2013 report found that looking at the production chain, rather than the individual stages of production, is more helpful. Individual donors with their own priorities and expertise cannot be expected to provide comprehensive response to the needs identified, not to mention the legal responsibilities of many specialist agencies. The research suggests they adjust their priorities and modalities to the way production chains operate, and to coordinate with other donors to cover all trade needs. It calls for donors and governments to work together to assess how aid flows may affect power relationships.<ref>{{cite web|author=Jodie Keane|date=2014|title=''Aid for trade and Global Value Chains: Issues for South Asia''|url=http://www.sawtee.org/publications/Policy-Brief-26.pdf|format=PDF|website=Sawtee.org|accessdate=19 April 2018}}</ref>
In his 1994 paper, Gereffi identified two major types of [[governance]]. The first were buyer-driven chains, where the lead firms are final buyers such as retail chains and branded product producers such as non-durable final consumer products (e.g., clothing, footwear and food). The second governance type identified by Gereffi were producer-driven chains. Here the technological competences of the lead firms (generally upstream in the chain) defined the chain’s competitiveness.
Current research suggests that GVCs exhibit a variety of characteristics and impact communities in a variety of ways. In a paper that emerged from the deliberations of the GVC Initiative,<ref>Gary Gereffi, John Humphrey, and Timothy Sturgeon, “The governance of global value chains,” ''Review of International Political Economy'', vol. 12, no. 1, 2005</ref> five GVC governance patterns were identified: * '''Hierarchical''' chains represent the fully internalised operations of [[Vertical integration|vertically integrated]] firms. * '''Quasi-hierarchical''' (or '''captive''' chains) involve suppliers or intermediate customers with low levels of capabilities, who require high levels of support and are the subject of well-developed supply chain management from lead firms (often called the chain governor). * '''Relational''' and '''modular''' chain governance exhibit durable relations between lead firms and their suppliers and customers in the chain, but with low levels of chain governance often because the main suppliers in the chain possess their own unique competences (and/or infrastructure) and can operate independently of the lead firm. * '''Market''' chains represent the classic arms length relationships found in many [[Commodity market|commodity markets]].
As capabilities in many low- and middle-income economies have grown, chain governance has tended to move away from quasi-hierarchical models toward modular type as this form of governance reduces the costs of supply chain management and allows chain governors to maintain a healthy level of competition in their supply chains. However, whilst it maintains short-term competition in the supply chain, it has allowed some leading intermediaries to develop considerable functional competences (e.g., design and branding). In the long term these have the potential to emerge as competitors to their original chain governor (Kaplinski, 2010).<ref>Kaplinsky, R. (2010), The Role of Standards in Global Value Chains and their Impact on Economic and Social Upgrading, Policy Research Paper 5396, World Bank</ref>
The theoretical concepts often considered firms as operating in a single value chain (with a single customer). Whilst this was often the case in quasi-hierarchical chains (with considerable customer power) it has become apparent that some firms operate in multiple value chains (subject to multiple forms of governance) and serve both national and international markets and that this plays a role in the development of firm capabilities (Navas-Aleman, 2011;<ref>Navas - Aleman, L. (2011) “The Impact of Operating in Multiple Value Chains for Upgrading: The Case of the Brazilian Furniture and Footwear Industries” World Development Vol. 39(8), pp. 1386 – 1397</ref> [[UNCTAD]], 2013).<ref name="unctad.org">{{cite web|url=http://unctad.org/en/PublicationsLibrary/wir2013_en.pdf|format=PDF|title=World Investment Report 2013: Global Value Chains: Investment and Trade for Development|website=Unctad.org|accessdate=19 April 2018}}</ref>
=== See also === * [[Agricultural value chain]]
=== Summary of Unctad report: global value chains and development === In 2013, [[UNCTAD]] published two reports on GVCs and their contribution to development. They concluded <ref name="unctad.org"/> that: * GVCs make a significant contribution to international development. Value-added trade contributes about 30% to the [[Gross domestic product|GDP]] of developing countries, significantly more than it does in developed countries (18%) furthermore the level of participation in GVCs is associated with stronger levels of [[List of countries by GDP (nominal) per capita|GDP per capita growth]]. GVCs thus have a direct impact on the economy, employment and income and create opportunities for development. They can also be an important mechanism for [[Developing country|developing countries]] to enhance productive capacity, by increasing the rate of adoption of technology and through workforce skill development, thus building the foundations for long-term industrial upgrading. * However, there are limitations to the GVC approach. Their contribution to the growth may be limited if the work done in-country is relatively low value adding (i.e. contributes only a small part of the total value added for the product or service). In addition there is no automatic process that guarantees diffusion of technology, skill-building and upgrading. Developing countries thus face the risk of operating in permanently low value-added activities. Finally, there are potential negative impacts on the environment and social conditions, including: poor workplace conditions, occupational safety and health, and job security. The relative ease with which the Value Chain Governors can relocate their production (often to lower cost countries) also create additional risks. * Countries need to carefully assess the pros and cons of GVC participation and the costs and benefits of proactive policies to promote GVCs or GVC-led development strategies. Promoting GVC participation implies targeting specific GVC segments and GVC participation can only form one part of a country’s overall development strategy. * Before promoting GVC participation, policymakers should evaluate their countries’ trade profiles and industrial capabilities in order to select strategic GVC development paths. Achieving upgrading opportunities through CVCs requires a structured approach that includes: ** embedding GVCs in industrial development policies (e.g. targeting GVC tasks and activities); ** enabling GVC growth by providing the right framework conditions for trade and FDI and by putting in place the needed infrastructure; and ** developing firm capabilities and training the local workforce.
==Gender and global value chains== Gender plays a prominent role in global value chains, because it influences consumption patterns within the United States, and thus affects production on a larger scale. In turn, specific roles within the value chain are also determined by gender, making gender a key component in the process as well. Far more women than men are found in the informal sector, as self-employed workers or subcontractors, while specific jobs and broader fields of work differ between men and women.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Carr|first1=Marilyn|last2=Chen|first2=Martha Alter|last3=Tate|first3=Jane|title=Globalization and Home-Based Workers|journal=Feminist Economics|date=200|volume=6|issue=3|pages=123–42|doi=10.1080/135457000750020164}}</ref>
===Women in global value chains=== Within the global value chains, it is often women who work in the weakest or most disadvantaged chains.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Watson|first1=Bruce|title=Economic Inequality for Women Costs $9tn Globally, study finds|work=The Guardian|date=23 January 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Sassen|first1=Saskia|title=Globalization and Its Discontents|date=1998|publisher=New Press}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Natsuda|first1=Kaoru|last2=Goto|first2=Kenta|last3=Thoburn|first3=John|title=Challenges To The Cambodian Garment Industry In The Global Garment Value Chain|journal=European Journal of Development Research|date=2010|volume=22|issue=4|pages=469–493|doi=10.1057/ejdr.2010.21}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Barrientos|first1=Stephanie|title=Gender, Flexibility and Global Value Chain|journal=IDS Bulletin|date=22 May 2009|issue=32|pages=83–93}}</ref>
Carr et al. argue that “the vast majority of subcontract workers or industrial homeworkers, who earn some of the lowest wages worldwide, are women.”

[[File:Cover KT Diss Print.jpg|thumb|230px|Front cover of [[Karl-Theodor zu Guttenberg]]'s thesis that led to his resignation.]] '''Guttenberg plagiarism scandal''' refers to the German political scandal that led to the resignation of [[Karl-Theodor zu Guttenberg]] as [[Federal Ministry of Defence (Germany)|Minister of Defence of Germany]] over the plagiarism of his doctoral dissertation. The first accusations of [[plagiarism]] in Guttenberg's dissertation were made public in February 2011. Guttenberg's doctoral dissertation, "{{lang|de|Verfassung und Verfassungsvertrag}}" ("Constitution and Constitutional Treaty"), had been the basis of his 2007 Doctorate from the [[University of Bayreuth]].<ref name="sz_doktorarbeit">{{cite news |url=http://www.sueddeutsche.de/politik/guttenbergs-doktorarbeit-summa-cum-laude-mehr-als-schmeichelhaft-1.1060779 |title=Summa cum laude? – „Mehr als schmeichelhaft“|author=Roland Preuß|work=sueddeutsche.de |date=2011-02-16 |accessdate=2011-02-22}}</ref><ref name="sz_plagiatsvorwurf">{{cite news|author=Roland Preuß and Tanjev Schultz |url=http://www.sueddeutsche.de/politik/plagiatsvorwurf-gegen-verteidigungsminister-guttenberg-soll-bei-doktorarbeit-abgeschrieben-haben-1.1060774 |title=Plagiatsvorwurf gegen Verteidigungsminister: zu Guttenberg soll bei Doktorarbeit abgeschrieben haben|work=sueddeutsche.de |date=2011-02-16 |accessdate=2011-02-21}}</ref> Guttenberg at first denied intentional plagiarism, calling the accusations "absurd," but acknowledged that he may have made errors in his footnotes.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.spiegel.de/politik/deutschland/0,1518,745919,00.html |title=Fußnoten-Streit: Dr. Guttenberg nennt Plagiatsvorwürfe abstrus|work=Spiegel Online |date=2011-02-16 |accessdate=2011-02-21}}</ref><ref name="bbc-minister-denies">{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-12489762 |title=German minister denies plagiarism on PhD thesis |publisher=BBC News |date=2011-02-17 |accessdate=2016-11-21}}</ref><ref name="guardian-resignation">{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/mar/01/german-defence-minister-resigns-plagiarism |title=German defence minister resigns in PhD plagiarism row |author=Helen Pidd |publisher=The Guardian |date=2011-03-01 |accessdate=2016-11-21}}</ref> In addition, it emerged that Guttenberg had requested a report from the Bundestag's research department, which he had then inserted into his thesis without attribution.<ref name="spiegel-accusations-widen">{{cite news |url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/germany/plagiarism-accusations-widen-guttenberg-copied-work-of-german-parliament-s-research-department-a-746573.html |title=Plagiarism Accusations Widen: Guttenberg Copied Work of German Parliament's Research Department |publisher=Spiegel Online |date=2011-02-19 |accessdate=2016-11-21}}</ref> On 23 February 2011, Guttenberg apologized in [[Bundestag (Germany)|parliament]] for flaws in his thesis, but denied intentional deception and denied the use of a ghostwriter.<ref name="reuters-admits-mistakes">{{cite news |url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-germany-minister-plagiarism-idUKTRE71M4JY20110223 |title=German minister admits mistakes in plagiarism row |author=Erik Kirschbaum |publisher=Reuters |date=2011-02-23 |accessdate=2016-11-21}}</ref>
On 23 February 2011, the University of Bayreuth withdrew Guttenberg's doctorate.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.spiegel.de/politik/deutschland/0,1518,747358,00.html|title=Uni Bayreuth entzieht Guttenberg den Doktortitel|publisher=Spiegel Online|date=2011-02-23|accessdate=2012-02-01}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.dw.com/en/german-defense-minister-loses-doctorate-amid-plagiarism-scandal/a-14860585 |title=German defense minister loses doctorate amid plagiarism scandal |publisher=Deutsche Welle |date=2011-02-23 |accessdate=2016-11-21}}</ref> In part due to the expressions of confidence by Angela Merkel, the scandal continued to evoke heavy criticism from prominent academics, legal scholars (who accused Guttenberg of intentional plagiarism), and politicians both in the opposition and in the governing coalition.<ref>{{cite news|author=Rudolf Neumaier |url=http://www.sueddeutsche.de/politik/plagiatsaffaere-um-guttenberg-wir-sind-einem-betrueger-aufgesessen-1.1065263 |title=Plagiatsaffäre um Guttenberg „Einem Betrüger aufgesessen“|work=sueddeutsche.de |date=2011-02-26 |accessdate=2011-03-01}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.handelsblatt.com/politik/deutschland/plagiatsaffaere-juristen-unterstellen-guttenberg-vorsatz/3886578.html |title=Plagiatsaffäre: Juristen unterstellen Guttenberg Vorsatz |publisher=Handelsblatt |date=2011-02-26 |accessdate=2016-11-21}}</ref><ref name="spiegel-resignation">{{cite news |url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/germany/plagiarism-affair-defense-minister-guttenberg-resigns-a-748330.html |title=Plagiarism Affair: Defense Minister Guttenberg Resigns |publisher=Spiegel Online |date=2011-03-01 |accessdate=2016-11-21}}</ref> On 1 March 2011, Guttenberg announced his resignation as Minister of Defense, from his seat in the Bundestag, and from all other political offices.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-germany-guttenberg-idUSTRE7201WI20110301 |title=German defense minister quits in plagiarism row |author=Erik Kirschbaum |publisher=Reuters |date=2011-03-01 |accessdate=2016-11-21}}</ref>
In May 2011, a University of Bayreuth commission tasked with investigating Guttenberg's dissertation came to the conclusion that Guttenberg had engaged in intentional deception in the writing of his dissertation, and had violated standards of good academic practice.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.spiegel.de/lebenundlernen/uni/abschlussbericht-in-bayreuth-guttenberg-gibt-familie-mitschuld-an-doktorschmu-a-761868.html |title=Abschlussbericht in Bayreuth: Guttenberg gibt Familie Mitschuld an Doktorschmu |publisher=Spiegel Online |date=2011-05-11 |accessdate=2016-11-21}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.dw.com/en/university-says-ex-defense-minister-deliberately-cheated-on-thesis/a-15056863 |title=University says ex-defense minister 'deliberately cheated' on thesis |publisher=Deutsche Welle |date=2011-05-06 |accessdate=2016-11-21}}</ref> The commission found that he had included borrowed passages throughout his thesis, without citation, and had modified those passages in order to conceal their origin.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.welt.de/politik/deutschland/article13365134/Uni-Bayreuth-weist-Guttenbergs-Beteuerungen-zurueck.html |title=Uni Bayreuth weist Guttenbergs Beteuerungen zurück |publisher=Die Welt |date=2011-05-11 |accessdate=2016-11-21}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.badische-zeitung.de/deutschland-1/uni-bayreuth-guttenberg-hat-vorsaetzlich-getaeuscht--45177077.html |title=Uni Bayreuth: Guttenberg hat vorsätzlich getäuscht |publisher=Badische Zeitung |date=2011-05-12 |accessdate=2016-11-21}}</ref>
In November 2011, the prosecution in [[Hof, Bavaria|Hof]] discontinued the criminal proceedings for copyright violations against Guttenberg on condition of Guttenberg paying €20,000 to a charity. The prosecutor found 23 prosecutable copyright violations in Guttenberg's dissertation, but estimated that the material damage suffered by the authors of those texts was marginal.<ref name="sz-eingestellt">{{cite news |url=http://www.sueddeutsche.de/karriere/ermittlungen-in-plagiatsaffaere-eingestellt-guttenberg-kommt-glimpflich-davon-1.1197275 |title=Guttenberg kommt glimpflich davon |publisher=[[Süddeutsche Zeitung]] |date=2011-11-23 |accessdate=2016-11-24}}</ref><ref name="yahoo-ap-dropped">{{cite news |url=https://www.yahoo.com/news/prosecutors-drop-case-against-german-ex-minister-113344146.html |title=Prosecutors drop case against German ex-minister |publisher=[[Yahoo! News]] |agency=[[Associated Press]] |author=Geir Moulson |date=2011-11-23 |accessdate=2016-11-24}}</ref>
{{TOC limit}}
==Background== Guttenberg studied [[law]] at the [[University of Bayreuth]],<ref name="Muench">{{cite web|url=http://www.focus.de/politik/deutschland/portraet-der-herr-ist-so-frei_aid_371150.html|title=Der Herr ist so frei|language=German|publisher=Focus Online|date=2009-02-16|accessdate=2011-09-03}}</ref> where he passed the first legal [[Staatsexamen|state examination]] in 1999. In 2007, he was awarded a doctorate in law, under supervision of [[Peter Häberle]], with a dissertation on the development of [[constitutional law]] in the [[United States]] and the [[European Union]]. The doctoral thesis was titled "{{lang|de|Verfassung und Verfassungsvertrag. Konstitutionelle Entwicklungsstufen in den USA und der EU}}" (translation: "Constitution and Constitutional Treaties – Constitutional Steps of Development in the USA and the EU"). The university awarded the dissertation with the highest honor ''“[[summa cum laude]]”''.
==Loss of doctorate and resignation== ===Fischer-Lescano plagiarism review=== On 12 February 2011 [[Andreas Fischer-Lescano]], professor of law at the [[University of Bremen]], prepared a review of Guttenberg's thesis<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sueddeutsche.de/politik/guttengerg-affaere-verhasster-enthueller-1.1067213|title=Verhasster Enthüller|date=3 March 2011|publisher=Süddeutsche.de|language=German|accessdate=14 January 2014}}</ref> for the left-leaning<ref>{{cite web|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2011/02/18/uk-germany-minister-plagiarism-idUKTRE71H3FZ20110218|title=German minister faces investigation for "Copygate"|date=18 February 2011|publisher=REUTERS|accessdate=14 January 2014}}</ref> German legal quarterly “Kritische Justiz”.<ref name="wollte es nicht glauben">{{cite web|url=http://www.zeit.de/2011/09/Interview-Fischer-Lescano|title=Ich wollte es nicht glauben|date=24 February 2011|publisher=ZEIT ONLINE|language=German|accessdate=14 January 2014}}</ref> Fischer-Lescano was co-editor of this publication. During a reference check he discovered an article of the [[Neue Zürcher Zeitung]] (NZZ), published in 2003,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nzz.ch/aktuell/startseite/gott-hat-keinen-platz-in-der-europaeischen-verfassung-1.268200|title=Gott hat keinen Platz in der europäischen Verfassung|date=22 June 2003|publisher=Neue Zürcher Zeitung|language=German|accessdate=14 January 2014}}</ref> of which passages had been included in Guttenberg's thesis without citation.<ref name="wollte es nicht glauben" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/germany/guttenberg-s-printing-press-german-defense-minister-accused-of-plagiarism-a-745891.html|title=German Defense Minister Accused of Plagiarism|date=16 February 2011|publisher=SPIEGEL ONLINE International|language=German|accessdate=14 January 2014}}</ref> After this discovery Fischer-Lescano performed further searches and discovered seven more passages lacking proper citation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sueddeutsche.de/politik/guttenbergs-doktorarbeit-summa-cum-laude-mehr-als-schmeichelhaft-1.1060779|title=Summa cum laude? - "Mehr als schmeichelhaft"|date=16 February 2011|publisher=Süddeutsche.de|language=German|accessdate=14 January 2014}}</ref> He discussed the findings with the other editors of “Kritische Justiz” and they decided that their publication, with only 1,800 subscribers, was not the appropriate forum to make the findings public.<ref name="wollte es nicht glauben" /> So Fisher-Lescano contacted the German newspaper [[Süddeutsche Zeitung]] in [[Munich]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thelocal.de/20110216/33135|title=Guttenberg accused of plagiarizing PhD thesis|date=16 February 2011|publisher=The Local|accessdate=14 January 2014}}</ref>
On February 15, 2011 the newspaper contacted law professor [[Diethelm Klippel]], the Bayreuth University ombudsman, and informed him of the [[plagiarism]] charges.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uni-bayreuth.de/presse/Aktuelle-Infos/2011/Ablauf_15_03_2011.pdf|title=Dokumentation Fall Guttenberg Ablauf|date=15 March 2011|publisher=Universität Bayreuth|page=1|language=German|accessdate=14 January 2014}}</ref> Klippel had also been on the review committee for Guttenberg's doctoral thesis. On the same day the newspaper informed Guttenberg and gave him a few hours to respond to the allegations.<ref name="Es war kein Betrug">{{cite web|url=http://www.zeit.de/2011/48/DOS-Guttenberg/komplettansicht |title=Es war kein Betrug|date=26 November 2011|publisher=ZEIT ONLINE|accessdate=14 January 2014}}</ref> Guttenberg was on an official visit in [[Poland]] that day.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bmvg.de/portal/a/bmvg/!ut/p/c4/NYuxDsIwDET_yE4G1IgNVJBYYISypW0UGTVxZZyy8PEkA3fSG-7p8Im12W8UvRJnv-ADh4n24wfGtEV4cZG6QqJMbw1CJeG9feYAE-egjRqyUmUUryywsujSTBGpBmjGwdj-aKz5x37dadc757rucj3fcE3p8AP4zWWx/|title=Zu Guttenberg zu Gesprächen in Polen|date=16 February 2011|publisher=Bundesministerium der Verteidigung|language=German|accessdate=14 January 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.polen.pl/guttenberg-besuch-in-polen-von-plagiats-diskussion-uberschattet/|title=Guttenberg-Besuch in Polen von Plagiats-Diskussion überschattet|date=21 February 2011|publisher=Polen.pl|language=German|accessdate=14 January 2014}}</ref> Fischer-Lescano informed Guttenberg's thesis supervisors Peter Häberle and [[Rudolf Streinz]] about the charges.<ref name="wollte es nicht glauben" />
===Guttenberg offers resignation=== On 16 February 2011 the Süddeutsche Zeitung published an article reporting the allegations against Guttenberg.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sueddeutsche.de/politik/plagiatsvorwurf-gegen-verteidigungsminister-guttenberg-soll-bei-doktorarbeit-abgeschrieben-haben-1.1060774|title=Guttenberg soll bei Doktorarbeit abgeschrieben haben|newspaper=[[Süddeutsche Zeitung]]|date=16 February 2011|first=Roland|last=Preuß|first2=Tanjev|last2=Schultz}}</ref> On the same day the German newspaper [[Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung]] (FAZ) reported that the introduction of his thesis was borrowed from an FAZ-article from 1997, written by the political scientist Barbara Zehnpfennig.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.faz.net/aktuell/politik/inland/guttenberg-dissertation-anfang-bei-f-a-z-abgeschrieben-1593201.html|title=Anfang bei F.A.Z. abgeschrieben|date=16 February 2011|publisher=Frankfurter Allgemeine|language=German|accessdate=14 January 2014}}</ref>
In a first statement Guttenberg, who still was in Poland, called the charge, his thesis being a plagiarism, “abstruse”.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.zeit.de/politik/deutschland/2011-02/guttenberg-doktorarbeit-plagiat-reaktionen|title=Guttenberg weist Plagiatsvorwurf als "abstrus" zurück|date=16 February 2011|publisher=ZEIT ONLINE|language=German|accessdate=14 January 2014}}</ref><ref name="Plagiarism Row Plagues German Official">{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748703561604576150341564716876|title=Plagiarism Row Plagues German Official|date=18 February 2011|publisher=THE WALL STREET JOURNAL|accessdate=14 January 2014}}</ref> He insisted that the thesis was his own achievement and that none of his employees helped him to draft it.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/german-minister-rejects-plagiarism-allegations/|title=German Minister Rejects Plagiarism Allegations|date=16 February 2011|publisher=CBS News|accessdate=14 January 2014}}</ref> The University of Bayreuth delegated the allegations against Guttenberg to its Commission on Professional Self Regulation in Science.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uni-bayreuth.de/presse/Aktuelle-Infos/2011/Ablauf_15_03_2011.pdf|title=Dokumentation Fall Guttenberg Ablauf|date=15 March 2011|publisher=Universität Bayreuth|pages=1–2|language=German|accessdate=14 January 2014}}</ref> On 16 February 2011, after his return from Poland, Guttenberg left for a surprise visit to German soldiers in [[Afghanistan]].<ref name="Plagiarism Row Plagues German Official" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nzz.ch/aktuell/international/guttenberg-in-afghanistan-1.9563983|title=Guttenberg in Afghanistan|date=17 February 2011|publisher=Neue Zürcher Zeitung|language=German|accessdate=14 January 2014}}</ref> He spent the night in the military camp “OP North” in the war zone [[Baghlan province]].<ref name=" An zwei Fronten">{{cite web|url=http://www.faz.net/aktuell/politik/inland/2.1673/mit-guttenberg-in-afghanistan-an-zwei-fronten-1594642.html|title=An zwei Fronten|date=20 February 2011|publisher=Frankfurter Allgemeine|language=German|accessdate=14 January 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dw.de/german-defense-minister-on-a-surprise-visit-to-afghanistan/a-6441641|title=German defense minister on a surprise visit to Afghanistan|date=17 February 2011|publisher=Deutsche Welle|accessdate=14 January 2014}}</ref> Although the visit had been planned weeks in advance, allegations were raised, that this trip was some kind of “getaway” for Guttenberg.<ref name=" An zwei Fronten"/>
Guttenberg returned the next day, 17 February 2011, and had a meeting with [[Chancellor of Germany|German chancellor]] [[Angela Merkel]].<ref name=" An zwei Fronten" /> His offer to resign was refused by Merkel.<ref name="Es war kein Betrug" /> The same day the University of Bayreuth sent a letter to Guttenberg conceding him two weeks to respond to the plagiarism allegations.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/germany/8331478/German-minister-given-deadline-in-plagiarism-row.html|title=German minister given deadline in plagiarism row|date=17 February 2011|publisher=The Telegraph|accessdate=14 January 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.zeit.de/politik/deutschland/2011-02/schnarrenberg-guttenberg-plagiatvorwurf|title=Uni Bayreuth setzt Guttenberg Frist|date=17 February 2011|publisher=ZEIT ONLINE|language=German|accessdate=14 January 2014}}</ref> The [[Crowdsourcing|crowd-source]] Guttenplag Wiki was launched by anonymous user PlagDoc as a platform for internet user to submit claims of unattributed work in Guttenberg's thesis.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://de.guttenplag.wikia.com/wiki/GuttenPlag_Wiki/English|title=GuttenPlag - collaborative documentation of plagiarism|publisher=Wikia|date=|accessdate=2011-08-18}}</ref><ref name="Im Schwarm">{{cite web|url=http://www.spiegel.de/spiegel/0,1518,775009-3,00.html|title=Im Schwarm|language=German|publisher=Spiegel Online|date=2011-07-18|accessdate=2011-09-07}}</ref><ref name="German minister rejects quitting in plagiarism row">{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/19/cnews-us-germany-minister-plagiarism-idCATRE71I24620110219|title=German minister rejects quitting in plagiarism row|date=19 February 2011|publisher=REUTERS|accessdate=14 January 2014}}</ref> A scheduled speech at an election campaign in [[Saxony-Anhalt]] was cancelled by Guttenberg<ref>{{cite news|last=Kelsey|first=Eric|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/17/us-germany-minister-plagiarism-idUSTRE71G6C720110217|title=German minister cancels speech amid plagiarism scandal|publisher=Reuters|date=17 February 2011|accessdate=1 March 2011}}</ref> because of his meeting with Angela Merkel.<ref name=" An zwei Fronten" />
The district attorney's office in [[Hof, Bavaria]], announced it would wait on the results of the Bayreuth University's examination of Guttenberg's thesis<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.justiz.bayern.de/sta/sta/ho/presse/archiv/2011/02950/|title=Strafanzeige gegen Bundesminister Freiherr zu Guttenberg|date=18 February 2011|publisher=Staatsanwaltschaft Hof|language=German|accessdate=14 January 2014}}</ref> and confirmed that two criminal complaints had been filed against Guttenberg, one regarding possible [[Copyright infringement|copyright violations]] and another on a possible false [[statutory declaration]]. The second was immediately declined by the attorney due to apparent insubstantiality.<ref name=" Regierung: „Das geht noch weiter“">{{cite web|url=http://www.faz.net/aktuell/politik/inland/2.1673/debatte-ueber-guttenbergs-dissertation-regierung-das-geht-noch-weiter-1597693.html|title=Regierung: "Das geht noch weiter"|date=18 February 2011|publisher=Frankfurter Allgemeine|language=German|accessdate=14 January 2014}}</ref> The same day the newspaper Süddeutsche Zeitung reported its findings that Guttenberg had used texts of 19 authors without correct attribution.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sueddeutsche.de/politik/plagiatsvorwuerfe-gegen-guttenberg-er-hat-es-mindestens-mal-gemacht-1.1062139|title=19 Ghostwriter wider Willen|date=18 February 2011|publisher=Süddeutsche.de|language=German|accessdate=14 January 2014}}</ref>
Chancellor Angela Merkel declared: “He has my full confidence for his work, and this work is important. He has my support […] and we must wait until the university has completed its examination of the allegations”.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dw.de/merkel-pledges-support-to-embattled-plagiarism-minister/a-14850899|title=Merkel pledges support to embattled 'plagiarism' minister|date=19 February 2011|publisher=Deutsche Welle|accessdate=14 January 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.welt.de/politik/deutschland/article12583321/Merkel-sichert-Guttenberg-volles-Vertrauen-zu.html|title=Merkel sichert Guttenberg "volles Vertrauen" zu|date=18 February 2011|publisher=DIE WELT|language=German|accessdate=14 January 2014}}</ref> In an interview the chancellor attested Guttenberg an “head-on approach” on the allegations.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.welt.de/politik/deutschland/article12588218/Merkel-bescheinigt-Guttenberg-offensives-Vorgehen.html|title=Merkel bescheinigt Guttenberg offensives Vorgehen|date=18 February 2011|publisher=DIE WELT|language=German|accessdate=14 January 2014}}</ref>
===Use of Parliamentary Research Service===
On February 19, 2011, the German news magazine [[Der Spiegel]] reported that Guttenberg had used works of the German Parliamentary Research Service (PRS) without proper attribution.<ref name="German minister rejects quitting in plagiarism row" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.spiegel.de/politik/deutschland/umstrittene-doktorarbeit-guttenberg-kopierte-auch-von-bundestagsdienst-a-746518.html|title=Guttenberg kopierte auch von Bundestagsdienst|date=19 February 2011|publisher=SPIEGEL ONLINE|language=German|accessdate=15 January 2014}}</ref> Any publication of PRS papers requires prior approval by the German Bundestag's departmental management.<ref name="n24.de">{{cite web|url=http://www.n24.de/n24/Nachrichten/Politik/d/1228724/guttenberg-raeumt-vor-bundestag-fehler-ein.html|title=Guttenberg räumt vor Bundestag Fehler ein|date=23 February 2011|publisher=N24|language=German|accessdate=15 January 2014}}</ref> During the weekend of February 20, 2011, Guttenberg re-read his thesis to examine Guttenplag's and other's findings.<ref name="Es war kein Betrug" />
[[File:Barcode zeilen.png|left|thumb|180px|Guttenplag claims of thesis’ pages containing one (black) or more (red) [[plagiarism]] fragments]] The next day in a letter Guttenberg asked the University of Bayreuth to revoke his title<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uni-bayreuth.de/presse/Aktuelle-Infos/2011/Ablauf_15_03_2011.pdf|title=Dokumentation Fall Guttenberg Ablauf|date=15 March 2011|publisher=Universität Bayreuth|pages=2–3|language=German|accessdate=15 January 2014}}</ref><ref name="Plagiatsaffäre: Guttenberg verzichtet dauerhaft auf Doktortitel">{{cite web|url=http://www.focus.de/politik/deutschland/plagiatsaffaere-guttenberg-verzichtet-dauerhaft-auf-doktortitel_aid_602194.html|title=Plagiatsaffäre: Guttenberg verzichtet dauerhaft auf Doktortitel|date=21 February 2011|publisher=FOCUS Online|language=German|accessdate=15 January 2014}}</ref> and declared that he had “lost track of the use of sources over the course of the seven years in which [he] worked on the thesis”, but “at no point made mistakes by intention”.<ref name="German defense minister loses doctorate amid plagiarism scandal">{{cite web|url=http://www.dw.de/german-defense-minister-loses-doctorate-amid-plagiarism-scandal/a-14860585|title=German defense minister loses doctorate amid plagiarism scandal|date=23 February 2011|publisher=Deutsche Welle|accessdate=15 January 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.spiegel.de/unispiegel/wunderbar/guttenberg-brief-an-uni-bayreuth-ueberblick-ueber-quellen-teilweise-verloren-a-747141.html|title=Guttenberg-Brief an Uni Bayreuth: "Überblick über Quellen teilweise verloren"|date=22 February 2011|publisher=SPIEGEL ONLINE|language=German|accessdate=15 January 2014}}</ref>
Also on 21 February 2011, chancellor Merkel reiterated her support for Guttenberg and told journalists “I appointed Guttenberg as Minister of Defence. I did not appoint him as an academic assistant or doctor. What is important to me is his work as Minister of Defence and he carries out these duties perfectly.”<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.faz.net/aktuell/politik/inland/plagiat-affaere-merkel-als-minister-ist-guttenberg-hervorragend-1594541.html|title=Merkel: Als Minister ist Guttenberg hervorragend|date=21 February 2011|publisher=Frankfurter Allgemeine|language=German|accessdate=15 January 2014}}</ref><ref name="German minister in plagiarism row stripped of PhD">{{cite web|url=http://reuters.com/article/2011/02/23/idINIndia-55105920110223?pageNumber=2|title=German minister in plagiarism row stripped of PhD|date=23 February 2011|publisher=REUTERS|accessdate=15 January 2014}}</ref> This statement caused anger in the German [[Academia|academic community]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.welt.de/politik/deutschland/article12658198/Wissenschaftler-werfen-Merkel-Verhoehnung-vor.html|title=Wissenschaftler werfen Merkel "Verhöhnung" vor|date=27 February 2011|publisher=DIE WELT|language=German|accessdate=15 January 2014}}</ref>
[[Annette Schavan]], [[Federal Ministry of Education and Research (Germany)|German minister of Education and Research]], who two years later had to resign herself because of plagiarism-accusations related to her own thesis,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/feb/09/german-education-minister-quits-phd-plagiarism|title=German education minister quits over PhD plagiarism|date=9 February 2013|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=15 January 2014}}</ref> declared, that she didn’t “consider the incident to be a trifle”, because “intellectual theft is not a small thing. The protection of intellectual property is a higher good.”<ref name=" Political Allies Blast Guttenberg: Support Wanes Fast for German Defense Minister ">{{cite web|url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/germany/political-allies-blast-guttenberg-support-wanes-fast-for-german-defense-minister-a-748197.html|title=Political Allies Blast Guttenberg: Support Wanes Fast for German Defense Minister|date=28 February 2011|publisher=SPIEGEL ONLINE International|accessdate=15 January 2014}}</ref> The same day it became known, that Guttenberg had used another PRS paper without proper citation.<ref name="Plagiatsaffäre: Guttenberg verzichtet dauerhaft auf Doktortitel" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.focus.de/politik/deutschland/guttenberg-weiteres-bundestags-gutachten-verwendet_aid_602178.html|title=Guttenberg: Weiteres Bundestags-Gutachten verwendet|date=21 February 2011|publisher=FOCUS Online|language=German|accessdate=15 January 2014}}</ref> That evening Guttenberg attended a campaign event in [[Kelkheim]]<ref name="German Defense Minister Defies Calls to Quit Over Plagiarism" /> and stated that he would give up his doctorate title permanently.<ref>{{cite news|last=Framke|first=Andreas|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/21/us-germany-minister-plagiarism-idUSTRE71K5S320110221|title=German minister gives up PhD title amid scandal|publisher=Reuters|date=21 February 2011|accessdate=1 March 2011}}</ref> “Over the weekend I had another look at my doctorate thesis”, Guttenberg declared and continued "I lost sight of the sources in one of two places. I wrote this piece of work myself and I stand by it, but I also stand by the rubbish I wrote".<ref name="German Defense Minister Defies Calls to Quit Over Plagiarism">{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/23/world/europe/23iht-germany23.html|title=German Defense Minister Defies Calls to Quit Over Plagiarism|date=22 February 2011|publisher=The New York Times|accessdate=16 January 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-22/merkel-backs-guttenberg-after-he-drops-doctor-title-amid-plagiarism-spat.html|title=Merkel Backs Guttenberg After He Drops Doctor Title Amid Plagiarism Spat|date=22 February 2011|publisher=Bloomberg|accessdate=15 January 2014}}</ref> Guttenberg admitted “serious mistakes”, which had not been intentionally<ref name=" Guttenberg Drops 'Doctor' to Save 'Minister'">{{cite web|url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/germany/political-superstar-under-pressure-guttenberg-drops-doctor-to-save-minister-a-746913.html|title=Guttenberg Drops 'Doctor' to Save 'Minister'|date=22 February 2011|publisher=SPIEGEL ONLINE International|accessdate=15 January 2014}}</ref> but “do not meet the ethical code of science”,<ref name="German minister gives up doctorate after plagiarism row">{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-12532877|title=German minister gives up doctorate after plagiarism row|date=22 February 2011|publisher=BBC NEWS|accessdate=15 January 2014}}</ref> and apologized to people, who had been hurt by his work.<ref name="Plagiatsaffäre: Guttenberg verzichtet dauerhaft auf Doktortitel" /> Guttenberg called his decision to give up the title “painfull”.<ref name="German Defense Minister Defies Calls to Quit Over Plagiarism" /> He rejected all speculation about his resignation and declared: “I will perform my duties with all my powers”.<ref name=" Guttenberg Drops 'Doctor' to Save 'Minister'" /> The University of Bayreuth confirmed the same day that Guttenberg had asked them to revoke his title.<ref name="German minister gives up doctorate after plagiarism row" /> Chancellor Merkel approved his decision to give up his title, a spokesman declared.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/german-minister-renounces-phd-after-accusations-of-plagiarism-2222828.html|title=German minister renounces PhD after accusations of plagiarism|date=23 February 2011|publisher=The Independent|accessdate=15 January 2014}}</ref>
