[[Image:Burattini Dragon.jpg|thumb|right|Burattini traveled worldwide, measured various structures, and designed machines like this "''{{lang|pl|Dragon Volant}}''" (lit. "Flying Dragon").]] '''Tito Livio Burattini''' ({{lang-pl|Tytus Liwiusz Burattini}}, 8 March 1617 – 17 November 1681) was an [[inventor]], [[architect]], [[Egyptology|Egyptologist]], [[scientist]], [[scientific instrument|instrument]]-maker, [[travel]]ler, [[engineer]], and [[nobleman]].<ref name="frysinger-1675">{{cite web|last=Frysinger|first=James R.|url=http://www.cofc.edu/~frysingj/background.htm|title=SI Background|work=SI Guide|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061010214505/http://www.cofc.edu/~frysingj/background.htm|archivedate=2006-10-10|accessdate=2009-05-24|deadurl=yes|df=}}</ref><ref name="needham591">{{cite book|last=Needham|first=Joseph|authorlink=Joseph Needham|title=[[Science and Civilisation in China]]|volume=IV (part 2)|year=1965|page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=SeGyrCfYs2AC&pg=PA591 591]|isbn=978-0-521-05803-2}}</ref><ref name="hamilton94">{{cite book|editor-last=Hamilton|editor-first=Alastair|editor2-last=van den Boogert|editor2-first=Maurits H|editor3-last=Westerweel|editor3-first=Bart|last=Shalev|first=Zur|chapter=The Travel Notebooks of John Greaves|title=The Republic of Letters and the Levant|publisher=[[Brill Publishers]]|year=2005|page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=BJDoAhXrMOUC&pg=PA94 94]|isbn=978-90-04-14761-4}}</ref> He was born in [[Agordo]], Italy, and studied in [[Padua]] and [[Venice]]. In 1639, he explored the [[Great Pyramid of Giza]] with English [[mathematician]] [[John Greaves]];<ref name="hamilton94" /><ref name="quarrie20">{{cite journal|last=Quarrie|first=Paul|url=http://rsnr.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/60/1/5.full.pdf|title=The Scientific Library of the Earls of Macclesfield|journal=[[Notes and Records of the Royal Society]]|volume=60|pages=5–24|doi=10.1098/rsnr.2005.0124|issn=0035-9149|year=2006}}</ref> both Burattini and Sir [[Isaac Newton]] used measurements made by Greaves in an attempt to accurately determine the circumference of the earth.<ref name="mehler26">{{cite book|last=Mehler|first=Stephen S.|year=2001<!--per book's copyright page-->|title=The Land of Osiris: An Introduction to Khemitology|publisher=[[David Hatcher Childress|Adventures Unlimited Press]]|page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=xqIxO3-M8ikC&pg=PA26 26]|isbn=978-0-932813-58-9}}</ref>
For [[Germany]] in 1641, the court of King [[Władysław IV Vasa|Władysław IV]] invited him to [[Poland]]. In [[Warsaw]], Burattini built a model aircraft with four fixed [[Glider aircraft|glider]] wings in 1647.<ref name="needham591" /> Described as "four pairs of wings attached to an elaborate 'dragon'", it was said to have successfully lifted a cat in 1648 but not Burattini himself.<ref name="harrison27">{{cite book|last=Harrison|first=James Pinckney|year=2000|title=Mastering the Sky|publisher=[[Da Capo Press]]|page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=JwJsr5QjkRMC&pg=PA27 27]|isbn=978-1-885119-68-1}}</ref> According to Clive Hart's ''The Prehistory of Flight'', he promised that "only the most minor injuries" would result from landing the craft.<ref name="oconner-1985">Qtd. in {{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1985/11/17/books/in-short-nonfiction-man-was-meant-to-fly-but-not-at-first.html|title=In Short: Nonfiction; Man Was Meant to Fly, But Not at First|last=O'Conner|first=Patricia T.|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=1985-11-17|accessdate=2009-05-24}}</ref>
He later developed an early [[Systems of measurement|system of measurement]] based on time, similar to today's [[International System of Units]]; he published it in his book ''{{lang|it|Misura universale}}'' (lit. "universal measure") in 1675 at [[Wilno]].<ref name="quarrie20" /> His system includes the ''{{lang|it|metro cattolico}}'' (lit. "[[wiktionary:catholic|catholic]] [i.e. universal] metre"), a [[unit of length]] equivalent to the length of a free [[seconds pendulum]]; it differs from the modern metre by half a centimetre.<ref>{{cite arxiv|last=Agnoli|first=Paolo|last2=D'Agostini|first2=Giulio|title=Why does the meter beat the second?|date=2005-01-25|eprint=physics/0412078 }}</ref> He is considered the first to recommend the name ''metre'' for a unit of length.
Along with two others he met at [[Kraków]], Burattini "performed optical experiments and contributed to the discovery of irregularities on the surface of [[Venus]], comparable to those on the Moon".<ref name="imss-burattini">{{cite web|url=http://brunelleschi.imss.fi.it/museum/esim.asp?c=300102|title=Tito Livio Burattini|work=[[Institute and Museum of the History of Science]] - Multimedia Catalogue - Biographies|accessdate=2009-05-24}}</ref> He made lenses for microscopes and telescopes, and gave some of them to Cardinal [[Leopoldo de' Medici]].<ref name="imss-burattini" /> He is also credited with building a calculating machine, which he donated to Grand Duke [[Ferdinando II de' Medici, Grand Duke of Tuscany|Ferdinando II]], that borrows from both a [[Blaise Pascal]] machine and [[Napier's bones|Napier's rods]].<ref name="imss-calculating">{{cite web|url=http://brunelleschi.imss.fi.it/mediciscienze/emed.asp?c=35423|title=Tito Livio Burattini <nowiki>[attr.]</nowiki>, Calculating machine|work=Institute and Museum of the History of Science - The Medici and Science|accessdate=2009-05-24}}</ref> He died in Kraków, aged 64.
==See also== *[[John Wilkins]]<!-- see [[Metre#History]] -->

MONACO, Alcune considerazioni sul «Maximus tubus» di Hevelius.}}"

{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2017}} {{Orphan|date=June 2016}} '''Vasiliev equations''' are ''formally'' consistent gauge invariant nonlinear equations whose linearization over a specific vacuum solution describes free massless higher-spin fields on anti-de Sitter space. The Vasiliev equations are classical equations and no Lagrangian is known that starts from canonical two-derivative Fronsdal Lagrangian and is completed by interactions terms. There is a number of variations of Vasiliev equations that work in three, four and arbitrary number of space-time dimensions. Vasiliev's equations admit supersymmetric extensions with any number of super-symmetries and allow for Yang-Mills gaugings. Vasiliev's equations are background independent, the simplest exact solution being anti-de Sitter space. It is important to note that locality is not properly implemented and the equations give a solution of certain formal deformation procedure, which is difficult to map to field theory language. The higher-spin [[AdS/CFT correspondence|AdS/CFT]] correspondence is reviewed in [[Higher-spin theory]] article.
The Vasiliev equations are generating equations and yield differential equations in the space-time upon solving them order by order with respect to certain auxiliary directions. The equations rely on several ingredients: unfolded equations and higher-spin algebras.
The exposition below is organised in such a way as to split the Vasiliev's equations into the building blocks and then join them together. The example of the four-dimensional bosonic Vasiliev's equations<ref name=VasFour>{{cite journal|last1=Vasiliev|first1=M.A.|title=Consistent equations for interacting gauge fields of all spins in 3+1 dimensions|journal=Physics Letters B|date=July 1990|volume=243|issue=4|pages=378–382|doi=10.1016/0370-2693(90)91400-6|bibcode=1990PhLB..243..378V}}</ref> is reviewed at length since all other dimensions and super-symmetric generalisations are simple modifications of this basic example. * the definition of the [[#Higher-Spin Algebra|higher-spin algebra]] is given since the higher-spin theory equations turns out to be the equations for two fields taking values in the higher-spin algebra; * the specific star-product that the fields that enter Vasiliev's equations take values in is defined; * part of the Vasiliev equations is related to an interesting deformation of the Harmonic oscillator, called [[#Deformed oscillators|deformed oscillators]], which is reviewed; * the [[#Unfolded Equations|unfolded approach]] is discussed, which is a slightly advanced form of writing the differential equations in the first order form; * the [[#Vasiliev's Equations|Vasiliev equations]] are given; * it is proved that the linearisation of Vasiliev's equations over anti-de Sitter space describes free massless higher-spin fields.
Three variations of Vasiliev's equations are known: four-dimensional,<ref name=VasFour/> three-dimensional<ref name=VasThree>{{cite journal|last1=VASILIEV|first1=M.A.|title=EQUATIONS OF MOTION FOR d=3 MASSLESS FIELDS INTERACTING THROUGH CHERN–SIMONS HIGHER-SPIN GAUGE FIELDS|journal=Modern Physics Letters A|date=21 December 1992|volume=07|issue=39|pages=3689–3702|doi=10.1142/S0217732392003116|bibcode=1992MPLA....7.3689V}}</ref><ref name=VasProk>{{cite journal|last1=Prokushkin|first1=S.F.|last2=Vasiliev|first2=M.A.|title=Higher-spin gauge interactions for massive matter fields in 3D AdS space-time|journal=Nuclear Physics B|date=April 1999|volume=545|issue=1–3|pages=385–433|doi=10.1016/S0550-3213(98)00839-6|arxiv=hep-th/9806236|bibcode=1999NuPhB.545..385P}}</ref> and d-dimensional.<ref name=VasD>{{cite journal|last1=Vasiliev|first1=M.A.|title=Nonlinear equations for symmetric massless higher spin fields in (A)dSd|journal=Physics Letters B|date=August 2003|volume=567|issue=1–2|pages=139–151|doi=10.1016/S0370-2693(03)00872-4|arxiv=hep-th/0304049|bibcode=2003PhLB..567..139V}}</ref> They differ by mild details that are discussed below.
== Higher-spin algebras ==
Higher-spin algebras<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Vasiliev|first1=M. A.|title=Extended Higher-Spin Superalgebras and Their Realizations in Terms of Quantum Operators|journal=Fortschritte der Physik/Progress of Physics|date=1988|volume=36|issue=1|pages=33–62|doi=10.1002/prop.2190360104|bibcode=1988ForPh..36...33V}}</ref> are global symmetries of the higher-spin theory multiplet. The same time they can be defined as global symmetries of some [[Conformal field theory|conformal field theories]] (CFT), which underlies the kinematic part of the [[Higher-spin theory#Higher Spin AdS/CFT Correspondence|higher-spin AdS/CFT correspondence]], which is a particular case of the [[AdS/CFT correspondence|AdS/CFT]]. Another definition is that higher-spin algebras are quotients of the [[universal enveloping algebra]] of the anti-de Sitter algebra <math>so(d,2)</math> by certain two-sided ideals. Some more complicated examples of higher-spin algebras exist, but all of them can be obtained by tensoring the simplest higher-spin algebras with matrix algebras and then imposing further constraints. Higher-spin algebras originate as [[associative algebra]]s and the Lie algebra can be constructed via the commutator.
In the case of the four-dimensional bosonic higher-spin theory the relevant higher-spin algebra is very simple thanks to <math display="inline">so(3,2)\sim sp(4,\mathbb{R})</math> and can be built upon [[Quantum harmonic oscillator#N-dimensional harmonic oscillator|two-dimensional quantum Harmonic oscillator]]. In the latter case two pairs of creation/annihilation operators <math display="inline">a_1,a^\dagger_1, a_2,a_2^\dagger</math> are needed. These can be packed into the quartet <math display="inline">\hat{Y}^A, A=1,...,4</math> of operators obeying the canonical commutation relations :<math> [\hat{Y}^A,\hat{Y}^B]=2iC^{AB}\,, </math> where <math display="inline">C^{AB}=-C^{BA}</math> is the <math display="inline">sp(4)</math> invariant tensor, i.e. it is anti-symmetric. As is well known, the bilinears provide an oscillator realization of <math display="inline">sp(4)</math>: :<math> T^{AB}=-\frac{i}4\{\hat{Y}^A,\hat{Y}^B\}\,, \qquad [T^{AB},T^{CD}]=T^{AD}C^{BC}+\text{3 more}\,. </math> The higher-spin algebra is defined as the algebra of all even functions <math display="inline">f(\hat{Y}), f(\hat{Y})=f(-\hat{Y})</math> in <math display="inline">\hat{Y}^A</math>. That the functions are even is in accordance with the bosonic content of the higher-spin theory as <math display="inline">\hat{Y}^A</math> will be shown to be related to the Majorana spinors from the space-time point of view and even powers of <math display="inline">\hat{Y}^A</math> correspond to tensors. It is an associative algebra and the product is conveniently realised by the [[Moyal product|Moyal star product]]: :<math> (f\star g)(Y)=f(Y)\exp i\left({\frac{\overleftarrow{\partial}}{\partial Y^A} C^{AB} \frac{\overrightarrow{\partial}}{\partial Y^B }}\right)g(Y)\,, </math> with the meaning that the algebra of operators <math display="inline">f(\hat{Y})</math> can be replaced with the algebra of function <math display="inline">f(Y)</math> in ordinary commuting variables <math display="inline">{Y}^A</math> (hats off) and the product needs to be replaced with the non-commutative star-product. For example, one finds :<math> (Y^A \star g)(Y)=(Y^A+iC^{AB}\partial_B)g(Y)\,, \qquad (f \star Y^B)(Y)=(Y^B-iC^{BA}\partial_B)f(Y)\,, </math> and therefore <math display="inline">Y^A\star Y^B-Y^B\star Y^A=[Y^A,Y^B]_\star=2iC^{AB}</math> as it would be the case for the operators. Another representation of the same star-product is more useful in practice: :<math> (f\star g)(Y)=\frac{1}{(2\pi)^4}\int dU dV f(Y+U) g(Y+V) e^{iU_A V_BC^{AB}}\,. </math> The exponential formula can be derived by integrating by parts and dropping the boundary terms. The prefactor is chosen as to ensure <math>1\star 1=1</math>. In the Lorentz-covariant base we can split <math display="inline">A=\alpha,\dot{\alpha};\alpha=1,2;\dot{\alpha}=1,2</math> and we also split <math>Y^A=y^\alpha,y^{\dot{\alpha}}</math>. Then the Lorentz generators are <math display="inline">L^{\alpha\beta}=T^{\alpha\beta}</math>, <math display="inline">\bar{L}^{\dot{\alpha}\dot{\beta}}=T^{\dot{\alpha}\dot{\beta}}</math> and the translation generators are <math display="inline">P^{\alpha\dot{\beta}}=T^{{\alpha}\dot{\beta}}</math>. The <math display="inline">\pi</math>-automorphism can be realized in two equivalent ways: either as <math display="inline">\pi(y^\alpha)=-y^\alpha, \pi(y^{\dot{\alpha}})=y^{\dot{\alpha}}</math> or as <math display="inline">\pi(y^\alpha)=Y^\alpha, \pi(y^{\dot{\alpha}})=-y^{\dot{\alpha}}</math>. In both the cases it leaves the Lorentz generators untouched and flips the sign of translations.
The higher-spin algebra constructed above can be shown to be the symmetry algebra of the three-dimensional [[Klein–Gordon equation|Klein-Gordon equation]] <math>\square_3 \phi(x)=0</math>. Considering more general free CFT's, e.g. a number of scalars plus a number of fermions, the Maxwell field and other, one can construct more examples of higher-spin algebras.
== Vasiliev star-product ==
The Vasiliev equations are equations in certain bigger space endowed with auxiliary directions to be solved for. The additional directions are given by the doubles of <math display="inline">{Y}^A</math>, called <math display="inline">{Z}^A</math>, which are furthermore entangled with Y. The star-product on the algebra of functions in <math display="inline">f(Y,Z)</math> in <math display="inline">{Y}, Z</math>-variables is :<math>F(Y,Z)\star G(Y,Z) =\frac{1}{(2\pi)^4}\int dU\, dV\, F(Y+U,Z+U) G(Y+V,Z-V)\exp{[i U_A V_B C^{AB}]}\,. </math> The integral formula here-above is a particular star-product that corresponds to the Weyl ordering among Y's and among Z's, with the opposite signs for the commutator: :<math> [Y^A,Y^B]=2iC^{AB}\,, \qquad\qquad [Z^A,Z^B]=-2i C^{AB} \,. </math> Moreover, the Y-Z star product is normal ordered with respect to Y-Z and Y+Z as is seen from :<math> \begin{align}F(a,a^\dagger)\star G(a,a^\dagger) &=\frac{1}{(2\pi)^4}\int dU\, dV\, F(a+2U,a^\dagger) G(a,a^\dagger+2V)\exp{[i U_A V_B C^{AB}]} \,, &\quad a=Y+Z\,, a^\dagger =Y-Z\end{align}</math>
The higher-spin algebra is an associative subalgebra in the extended algebra. In accordance with the bosonic projection is given by <math>f(Y,Z)=f(-Y,-Z)</math>.
== Deformed oscillators ==
The essential part of the Vasiliev equations relies on an interesting deformation of the [[Quantum harmonic oscillator]], known as deformed oscillators. First of all, let us pack the usual creation and annihilation operators <math display="inline">a^\dagger, a</math> in a doublet <math display="inline">q_\alpha\,,\alpha=1,2</math>. The canonical commutation relations (the <math display="inline">2i</math>-factors are introduced to facilitate comparison with Vasiliev's equations) :<math>\left[q_\alpha,q_\beta\right]=-2i\epsilon_{\alpha\beta}\,, \qquad \epsilon_{\alpha\beta}=\begin{bmatrix} 0 &1 \\-1 &0\end{bmatrix}\,,</math> can be used to prove that the bilinears in <math>q_\alpha</math> form <math>sp(2)\sim sl(2)</math> generators :<math> \begin{align} T_{\alpha\beta}&=\frac{i}{4}\{q_\alpha,q_\beta\}\,, \\ \left[T_{\alpha\beta},q_\gamma\right]&= q_\alpha \epsilon_{\beta\gamma}+q_\beta \epsilon_{\alpha\gamma} \,,\\ \left[T_{\alpha\beta},T_{\gamma\delta}\right]&=T_{\alpha\delta}\epsilon_{\beta\gamma}+T_{\beta\delta}\epsilon_{\alpha\gamma}+T_{\alpha\gamma}\epsilon_{\beta\delta}+T_{\beta\gamma}\epsilon_{\alpha\delta}\,. \end{align} </math> In particular, <math>T_{\alpha\beta}</math> rotates <math>q_\alpha</math> as an <math>sp(2)</math>-vector with <math>\epsilon_{\alpha\beta}</math> playing the role of the <math>sp(2)</math>-invariant metric. The deformed oscillators are defined<ref>{{cite journal|last1=VASILIEV|first1=M.A.|title=HIGHER SPIN ALGEBRAS AND QUANTIZATION ON THE SPHERE AND HYPERBOLOID|journal=International Journal of Modern Physics A|date=20 March 1991|volume=06|issue=07|pages=1115–1135|doi=10.1142/S0217751X91000605|bibcode=1991IJMPA...6.1115V}}</ref> by appending the set of generators with an additional generating element <math>Q</math> and postulating :<math> \{q_\alpha, Q\}=0\,, \qquad \left[q_\alpha,q_\beta\right]=-2i\epsilon_{\alpha\beta}(1+Q)\,. </math> Again, one can see that <math>T_{\alpha\beta}</math>, as defined above, form <math>sp(2)</math>-generators and rotate properly <math>q_\alpha</math>. At <math>Q=0</math> we get back to the undeformed oscillators. In fact, <math>q_\alpha</math> and <math>T_{\alpha\beta}</math> form the generators of the [[Lie superalgebra]] <math>osp(1|2)</math>, where <math>q_\alpha</math> should be viewed as odd generators. Then, <math>\{q_\alpha,q_\beta\}=-4iT_{\alpha\beta}</math> is the part of the defining relations of <math>osp(1|2)</math>. One (or two) copies of the deformed oscillator relations form a part of the Vasiliev equations where the generators are replaced with fields and the commutation relations are imposed as field equations.
== Unfolded equations ==
The equations for higher-spin fields originate from the Vasiliev equations in the unfolded form. Any set of differential equations can be put in the first order form by introducing auxiliary fields to denote derivatives. Unfolded approach<ref name=Unfolding>{{cite journal|last1=Vasiliev|first1=M.A|title=Consistent equations for interacting massless fields of all spins in the first order in curvatures|journal=Annals of Physics|date=February 1989|volume=190|issue=1|pages=59–106|doi=10.1016/0003-4916(89)90261-3|bibcode=1989AnPhy.190...59V}}</ref> is an advanced reformulation of this idea that takes into account gauge symmetries and diffeomorphisms. Instead of just <math display="inline">\partial_\mu \phi^i(x)=f_\mu^i(\phi)</math> the unfolded equations are written in the language of differential forms as :<math> d W^A =F^A(W)\,, </math> where the variables are [[differential form]]s <math display="inline">W^A=W^A_{\mu_1...\mu_q}(x)\,dx^{\mu_1}\wedge...\wedge dx^{\mu_q}</math> of various degrees, enumerated by an abstract index <math display="inline">A</math>; <math display="inline">d</math> is the [[exterior derivative]] <math display="inline">d=dx^\mu\partial_\mu</math>. The structure function <math display="inline">F^A(W)</math> is assumed to be expandable in exterior product Taylor series as :<math>F^A(W)=\sum_{q_1+...+q_n=q+1} F^A_{B_1...B_n} W^{B_1}\wedge ...\wedge W^{B_n}\,,</math> where <math display="inline">W^A</math> has form degree <math display="inline">q</math> and the sum is over all forms whose form degrees add up to <math display="inline">q+1</math>. The simplest example of unfolded equations are the zero curvature equations <math display="inline">d\omega=\tfrac12[\omega,\omega]</math> for a one-form connection <math display="inline">\omega</math> of any Lie algebra <math display="inline">\mathfrak{g}</math>. Here <math display="inline">A</math> runs over the base of the Lie algebra, and the structure function <math display="inline">F^A(\omega)=f^A_{BC}\,\omega^A\wedge \omega^B</math> encodes the structure constants of the Lie algebra.
Since <math display="inline">dd\equiv0</math> the consistency of the unfolded equations requires :<math>0\equiv ddW^A=dF^A(W)=dW^B\frac{\partial}{\partial W^B}F^A(W)=F^B\frac{\partial}{\partial W^B}F^A(W) \qquad \longleftrightarrow\qquad F^B\frac{\partial}{\partial W^B}F^A(W)=0 \,,</math> which is the [[Frobenius theorem (differential topology)|Frobenius integrability condition]]. In the case of the zero curvature equation this is just the Jacobi identity. Once the system is integrable it can be shown to have certain gauge symmetries. Every field <math display="inline">W^A</math> that is a form of non-zero degree <math display="inline">q</math> possesses a gauge parameter <math display="inline">\xi^A</math> that is a form of degree <math display="inline">q-1</math> and the gauge transformations are :<math>\delta W^A=d\xi^A+\xi^B\frac{\partial }{\partial W^B}F^A(W)</math>
The Vasiliev equations generate the unfolded equations for a specific field content, which consists of a one-form <math display="inline">\omega</math> and a zero-form <math display="inline">C</math>, both taking values in the [[#Higher-Spin Algebra|higher-spin algebra]]. Therefore, <math>W^A=(\omega,C)</math> and <math>\omega=\omega_\mu(Y|x)dx^\mu, \omega(Y|x)=\omega(-Y|x)</math>, <math>C=C(Y|x), C(Y|x)=C(-Y|x)</math>. The unfolded equations that describe interactions of higher-spin fields are :<math> \begin{align} d\omega&=\omega \star \omega +\mathcal{V}(\omega,\omega,C)+\mathcal{V}(\omega,\omega,C,C)+...\,,\\ dC&=\omega\star C-C\star \pi(\omega)+\mathcal{V}(\omega,C,C)+...\,, \end{align} </math> where <math display="inline">\mathcal{V}(\omega,...,C)</math> are the interaction vertices that are of higher and higher order in the <math display="inline">C</math>-field. The product in the higher-spin algebra is denoted by <math>\star</math>. The explicit form of the vertices can be extracted from the Vasiliev equations. The vertices that are bilinear in the fields are determined by the higher-spin algebra. [[Automorphism]] <math display="inline">\pi</math> is induced by the automorphism of the [[Anti-de Sitter space|anti-de Sitter]] algebra that flips the sign of translations, see below. If we truncate away higher orders in the <math display="inline">C</math>-expansion, the equations are just the zero-curvature condition for a connection <math display="inline">\omega</math> of the higher-spin algebra and the covariant constancy equation for a zero-form <math display="inline">C</math> that takes values in the twisted-adjoint representation<ref>{{cite book|last1=Greub|first1=Werner|title=Multilinear Algebra|date=1978|publisher=Springer US|location=New York, NY|isbn=1461394252|page=263|edition=2nd edition.|url=https://books.google.de/books?id=0Tz0BwAAQBAJ&lpg=PA263&ots=LvEcgFJ9lW&dq=twisted%20adjoint%20representation&pg=PA263#v=onepage&q=twisted%20adjoint%20representation&f=false}}</ref> (twist is by the automorphism <math display="inline">\pi</math>).
== Field content ==
The field content of the Vasiliev equations is given by three fields all taking values in the extended algebra of functions in Y and Z: * gauge connection <math>W=W_\mu(Y,Z|x)\, dx^\mu</math>, whose value at Z=0 gives the connection of the higher-spin algebra <math>\omega=\omega_\mu(Y|x)\, dx^\mu</math>. The bosonic projection implies <math>W(Y,Z|x)=W(-Y,-Z|x)</math>; * zero-form <math>B=B(Y,Z|x)</math>, whose value at Z=0 gives the zero-form of the higher-spin algebra <math>C=C(Y|x)</math>. The bosonic projection implies <math>B(Y,Z|x)=B(-Y,-Z|x)</math>; * an auxiliary field <math>S=S_A(Y,Z|x)\, dZ^A</math>, where it is sometimes useful to view it as a one-form in the auxiliary Z-space, hence the differentials: <math>dZ^A\wedge dZ^B=-dZ^B\wedge dZ^A\,.</math> :This field can be eliminated when solving for the Z-dependence. The bosonic projection for the <math>S</math>-field is <math>S_A(Y,Z|x)=-S_A(-Y,-Z|x)</math> due to the additional index <math>A</math> that is eventually carried by Y,Z.
As to avoid any confusion caused by the differential forms in the auxiliary Z-space and to reveal the relation to the [[#Deformed oscillators|deformed oscillators]] the Vasiliev equations are written below in the component form. The Vasiliev equations can be split into two parts. The first part contains only zero-curvature or covariant constancy equations: :<math> \begin{align} dW&=W\star W\,,\\ dB&=W\star B- B\star \pi(W)\,,\\ dS_A&=W\star S_A-S_A\star W\,, \end{align} </math> where the higher-spin algebra automorphism <math>\pi</math> is extended to the full algebra as :<math> \begin{align} \pi(W)(y_\alpha,y_{\dot{\alpha}},z_\alpha,z_{\dot{\alpha}})&={W}(-y_\alpha,y_{\dot{\alpha}},-z_\alpha,z_{\dot{\alpha}})={W}(y_\alpha,-y_{\dot{\alpha}},z_\alpha,-z_{\dot{\alpha}})\,, \end{align} </math> the latter two forms being equivalent because of the bosonic projection imposed on <math>W(Y,Z|X)</math>.
Therefore, the first part of the equations implies that there is no nontrivial curvature in the x-space since <math>W</math> is flat. The second part makes the system nontrivial and determines the curvature of the auxiliary connection <math>S</math>: :<math> \begin{align} \left[ S_A,S_B\right]_\star&=-2i\begin{bmatrix} \epsilon_{\alpha\beta} (1+B\star \varkappa) & 0 \\ 0 & \epsilon_{\dot{\alpha}\dot{\beta}}(1+B\star \bar{\varkappa}) \end{bmatrix}\,,\\ \{B\star \varkappa, S_\alpha\}_\star&=0\,, \\ \{B\star \bar{\varkappa}, S_{\dot{\alpha}}\}_\star&=0\,, \end{align} </math> where two Klein operators were introduced :<math>\varkappa=\exp{i y_\alpha z^\alpha}\,, \qquad \bar{\varkappa}=\exp{i y_{\dot{\alpha}} z^{\dot{\alpha}}}</math> The existence of the Klein operators is of utter importance for the system. They realise the <math>\pi</math> automorphism as an inner one :<math> \begin{align} \varkappa\star f(y_\alpha,y_{\dot{\alpha}},z_\alpha,z_{\dot{\alpha}})\star \varkappa&= f(-y_\alpha,y_{\dot{\alpha}},-z_\alpha,z_{\dot{\alpha}})\,, \qquad && \varkappa\star \varkappa=1\,,\\ \bar{\varkappa}\star f(y_\alpha,y_{\dot{\alpha}},z_\alpha,z_{\dot{\alpha}})\star \bar{\varkappa}&= f(y_\alpha,-y_{\dot{\alpha}},z_\alpha,-z_{\dot{\alpha}})\,, \qquad && \bar{\varkappa}\star \bar{\varkappa}=1\,. \end{align} </math> In other words, the Klein operator <math>\varkappa</math> behave as <math>(-1)^{N_y+N_z}</math>, i.e. it anti-commutes to odd functions and commute to even functions in y,z.
These 3+2 equations are the Vasiliev equations<ref name=VasFour/> for the four-dimensional bosonic higher-spin theory. Several comments are in order. * The algebraic part of the system when split into components <math>A=\alpha,\dot{\alpha}; \alpha=1,2; \dot{\alpha}=1,2</math> in accordance with the choice of the <math>sp(4)</math>-metric :<math>C_{AB}=\begin{bmatrix} \epsilon_{\alpha\beta} & 0 \\ 0 & \epsilon_{\dot{\alpha}\dot{\beta}} \end{bmatrix}</math> :becomes equivalent to two copies of the mutually commuting deformed oscillators: :<math> \begin{array}{lll} \left[S_{{\alpha}},S_{{\beta}}\right]=-2i\epsilon_{\alpha\beta} (1+B\star \varkappa) & \left[S_{{\alpha}},S_{\dot{\beta}}\right] =0 & \{B\star \varkappa, S_\alpha\}_\star=0\\ \left[S_{\dot{\alpha}},S_{{\beta}}\right]=0 & \left[S_{\dot{\alpha}},S_{\dot{\beta}}\right]=-2i\epsilon_{\dot{\alpha}\dot{\beta}}(1+B\star \bar{\varkappa}) & \{B\star \bar{\varkappa}, S_{\dot{\alpha}}\}_\star=0 \end{array}</math> :Therefore, the last two equations are equivalent to the definition relations of two copies of <math>osp(1|2)</math> with the <math>S_\alpha</math> and <math>S_{\dot{\alpha}}</math> playing the role of the odd generators and with <math>B\star \varkappa</math> and <math>B\star \bar{\varkappa}</math> playing the role of the deformations. Since <math>B</math> is the same for the two copies, they are not independent, which does not spoil the consistency. * The system is consistent. The consistency of the first three equations is obvious since they are zero-curvature/covariant-constancy equations. The consistency of the last two equations is thanks to the deformed oscillators. The mutual consistency of the two parts of the equations is thanks to fact that the twisted covariant constancy of the <math>B</math>-field is equivalent to the usual covariant constancy of either <math>B\star \varkappa</math> or <math>B\star \bar{\varkappa}</math>. Indeed, :<math>d (B\star \varkappa)-[W,(B\star \varkappa)]=(dB-W\star B+B\star \varkappa \star W \star \varkappa)\star \varkappa=(dB-W\star B+ B\star \pi(W))\star \varkappa=0</math> :where we used <math>\varkappa\star \varkappa=1</math> and its relation to the <math>\pi</math>-automorphism. Then, <math>\varkappa</math> can be cancelled since it is invertible; * The equations are gauge invariant. The gauge symmetry transformations with <math>\xi=\xi(Y,Z|x)</math> are: :<math> \begin{align} \delta W&= d\xi-[W,\xi]_\star\\ \delta B&=\xi\star B-B\star \pi(\xi)\\ \delta S_A&=\xi\star S_A-S_A\star \pi(\xi) \end{align}</math> * The equations are background independent and some vacuum needs to be specified in order to give an interpretation of the linearized solution * The simplest exact solution is the empty anti-de Sitter space: :<math> W=\Omega=\frac12 \varpi^{\alpha\alpha}L_{\alpha\alpha}+ h^{\alpha\dot{\alpha}} P_{\alpha\dot{\alpha}}+\frac12 \varpi^{\dot{\alpha}\dot{\alpha}}\bar{L}_{\dot{\alpha}\dot{\alpha}}\,, \qquad B=0\,, \qquad S_A=Z_A\,, </math> :where <math>\Omega</math> is a flat connection <math>d\Omega=\Omega\star \Omega</math> of the anti-de Sitter algebra and the components along the Lorentz and translations generators correspond to spin-connection <math>\varpi^{\alpha\alpha}, \varpi^{\dot{\alpha}\dot{\alpha}}</math> and vierbein <math> h^{{\alpha}\dot{\alpha}}</math>, respectively. It is important that the <math>S</math>-field has a nontrivial vacuum value, which is a solution due to <math>[Z_A,Z_B]_\star=-2iC_{AB}</math> and the fact that <math>B=0</math>. * The Vasiliev equations linearized over the anti-de Sitter vacuum do describe all free massless fields of spin s=0,1,2,3,..., which requries some computation and is shown below.
== Linearization ==
To prove that the linearized Vasiliev equations do describe free massless higher-spin fields we need to consider the linearised fluctuations over the anti-de Sitter vacuum. First of all we take the exact solution where <math>W=\Omega</math> is a flat connection of the anti-de Sitter algebra, <math>B=0</math> and <math>S_A=Z_A</math> and add fluctuations :<math>W=\Omega + w\,, \qquad B=0+2ib\,, \qquad S_A=Z_A+2is_A\,.</math> Then, we linearize the Vasiliev equations :<math> \begin{align} dw-\Omega\star w-w\star\Omega&=0\,,\\ db-\Omega\star b+b\star \pi(\Omega)&=0\,,\\ ds_A-\Omega\star s_A+s_A\star \Omega&= \partial_A w\,,\\ \partial_A b&=0\,,\\ \partial_\alpha s_\beta-\partial_\beta s_\alpha &=\epsilon_{\alpha\beta}b\star \varkappa\,,\\ \partial_{\dot{\alpha}} s_{\dot{\beta}}-\partial_{\dot{\beta}} s_{\dot{\alpha}} &=\epsilon_{\dot{\alpha}\dot{\beta}}b\star \bar{\varkappa}\,,\\ \partial_\alpha s_{\dot{\beta}}-\partial_{\dot{\beta}}s_\alpha&=0 \,, \end{align} </math> Above it was used several times that <math display="inline">[Z^A, f(Z)]_\star=-2i\partial_A f(Z), \partial_A\equiv\frac{\partial}{\partial Z^A}</math>, i.e. the vacuum value of the S-field acts as the derivative under the commutator. It is convenient to split the four-component Y,Z into two-component variables as <math>Y^A=(y^\alpha,y^{\dot{\alpha}}), Z^A=(z^\alpha,z^{\dot{\alpha}})</math>. Another trick that was used in the fourth equation is the invertibility of the Klein operators: :<math>\{b\star \varkappa, z_\alpha\}=b\star \varkappa\star z_\alpha+z_\alpha\star b\star \varkappa= (b\star \varkappa\star z_\alpha\star\varkappa+z_\alpha\star b)\star \varkappa=[z_\alpha,b]\star\varkappa\,.</math> The fifth of the Vasiliev equations is now split into the last three equation above.
The analysis of the linearized fluctuations is in solving the equations one by one in the right order. Recall that one expects to find unfolded equations for two fields: one-form <math>\omega=\omega_\mu(Y|x)dx^\mu</math> and zero-form <math>C=C(Y|x)</math>. From the fourth equation it follows that <math>b</math> does not depend on the auxiliary Z-direction. Therefore, one can identify <math>b=C(Y|x)</math>. The second equation then immediately leads to :<math>\nabla C +ih^{\alpha\dot{\alpha}}\left(y_\alpha y_{\dot{\alpha}}-\frac{\partial^2}{\partial y^\alpha\partial y^{\dot{\alpha}}}\right)C=0\,,</math> where <math>\nabla</math> is the Lorentz covariant derivative :<math>\nabla=d-\varpi^{\alpha\beta}\left(y_\alpha\frac{\partial}{\partial y^\beta}+y_\beta\frac{\partial}{\partial y^\alpha}\right)-...</math> where ... denote the term with <math>\varpi^{\dot{\alpha}\dot{\beta}}</math> that is similar to the first one. The Lorentz covariant derivative comes from the usual commutator action of the spin-connection part of <math>\Omega</math>. The term with the vierbein results from the <math>\pi</math>-automorphism that flips the sign of the AdS-translations and produces anti-commutator <math>h^{\alpha\dot{\alpha}}\left\{P_{\alpha\dot{\alpha}},\bullet\right\}_\star</math>.
To read off the content of the C-equation one needs to expand it in Y and analyze the C-equation component-wise :<math>C=\sum_{k+m= \text{even}}C_{\alpha_1...\alpha_k,\dot{\alpha}_1...\dot{\alpha}_m}(X)\,y^{\alpha_1}...y^{\alpha_k}\,y^{\dot{\alpha}_1}...y^{\dot{\alpha}_m}</math> Then various components can be seen to have the following interpretation: * The very first component <math>C(x)</math> is the scalar field. The one next to it, <math>C_{\alpha\dot{\alpha}}</math> is expressed by virtue of the C-equation as the derivative of the scalar. One of the component equations imposes the Klein-Gordon equation <math>(\square -2)C(x)=0</math>, where the cosmological constant is set to one. The components with equal number of dotted and undotted indices are expressed as on-shell derivatives of the scalar :<math>C_{\alpha_1...\alpha_k,\dot{\alpha}_1...\dot{\alpha}_k}(x)\,h^{\alpha_1\dot{\alpha}_1}_{\mu_1}...h^{\alpha_k\dot{\alpha}_k}_{\mu_k}\sim \nabla_{\mu_1}...\nabla_{\mu_k}C(x)</math> * <math>C_{\alpha\beta}, C_{\dot{\alpha}\dot{\beta}}</math> are the self-dual and anti self-dual components of the [[Electromagnetic tensor|Maxwell tensor]] <math>F_{\mu\nu}</math>. The C-equation imposes the Maxwell equations. The components with k+2=m and k=m+2 are on-shell derivatives of the Maxwell tensor; * <math>C_{\alpha\beta\gamma\delta}, C_{\dot{\alpha}\dot{\beta}\dot{\gamma}\dot{\delta}}</math> are the self-dual and anti self-dual components of the [[Weyl tensor]] <math>C_{\mu\nu,\lambda\rho}</math>. The C-equation imposes the Bianchi identities for the Weyl tensor. The components with k+4=m and k=m+4 are on-shell derivatives of the Weyl tensor; * <math>C_{\alpha_1...\alpha_{2s}}, C_{\dot{\alpha}_1...\dot{\alpha}_{2s}}</math> are the self-dual and anti self-dual components of the higher-spin generalization of the Weyl tensor. The C-equation imposes the Bianchi identities and the components with k+2s=m and k=m+2s are on-shell derivatives of the higher-spin Weyl tensor;
The last three equations can be recognized to be the equations of the form <math>\mathrm{d}\mu=\nu, \mathrm{d}\nu=0</math> where <math>\mathrm{d}</math> is the exterior derivative on the space of differential forms in the Z-space. Such equations can be solved with the help of the [[Closed and exact differential forms|Poincare Lemma]]. In addition one needs to know how to multiply by the Klein operator from the right, which is easy to derive from the integral formula for the star-product: :<math>f(y_\alpha,z_\beta)\star \varkappa=f(-z_\alpha,-y_\beta)\varkappa\,.</math> I.e. the result is to exchange the half of the Y and Z variables and to flip the sign. The solution to the last three equations can be written as :<math>s_\alpha= z_\alpha \int_0^1 t\,dt\, C(-zt,\bar{y})e^{ity^\alpha z_\alpha}+\partial_\alpha \epsilon\,,</math> where a similar formula exists for <math>s_{\dot{\alpha}}</math>. Here the last term is the gauge ambiguity, i.e. the freedom to add exact forms in the Z-space, and <math>\epsilon=\epsilon(Y,Z|x)</math>. One can gauge fix it to have <math>\partial_\alpha\epsilon=0</math>. Then, one plugs the solution to the third equation, which of the same type, i.e. a differential equation of the first order in the Z-space. Its general solution is again given by the Poincare Lemma :<math>w=\omega+Z^A\int_0^1dt\, f_A(zt)\,,\qquad f_A=dS_A-[\Omega,S_A]_\star\,,</math> where <math>\omega=\omega(Y|x)</math> is the integration constant in the Z-space, i.e. the [[De Rham cohomology|de-Rham cohomology]]. It is this integration constant that is to be identified with the one-form <math>\omega(Y|x)</math> as the name suggests. After some algebra one finds :<math>w=\omega+\int_0^1dt(1-t)\left(t\varpi^{\alpha\beta}z_\alpha z_\beta-ih^{\alpha\dot{\alpha}}z_\alpha\frac{\partial}{\partial y^{\dot{\alpha}}}\right)C(-z_\gamma t,y_{\dot{\gamma}})e^{ity^\delta z_\delta}+...</math> where we again dropped a term with dotted and undotted indices exchanged. The last step is to plug the solution into the first equation to find :<math>\nabla \omega -h^{\alpha\dot{\alpha}}\left(y_\alpha\frac{\partial}{\partial y^{\dot{\alpha}}}+y_{\dot{\alpha}}\frac{\partial}{\partial y^\alpha}\right)\omega=-\frac{1}{2} h_\gamma{}^{\dot{\alpha}}\wedge h^{\gamma\dot{\beta}}\frac{\partial^2}{\partial y^{\dot{\alpha}} \partial y^{\dot{\beta}}}C(0,y_{\dot{\delta}})+...</math> and again the second term on the right is omitted. It is important that <math>\omega</math> is not a flat connection, while <math>w</math> is a flat connection. To analyze the <math>\omega</math>-equations it is useful to expand <math>\omega</math> in Y :<math>\omega=\sum_{k+m= \text{even}}\omega_{\alpha_1...\alpha_k,\dot{\alpha}_1...\dot{\alpha}_m}(X)\,y^{\alpha_1}...y^{\alpha_k}\,y^{\dot{\alpha}_1}...y^{\dot{\alpha}_m}</math> The content of the <math>\omega</math>-equation is as follows: * The diagonal components with k=m are the higher-spin vierbeins, whose totally-symmetric component can be identified with the [[Higher-Spin gauge theory#Fronsdal Fields|Fronsdal field]] as :<math>h_{\mu_1}^{\alpha_1\dot{\alpha}_1}... h_{\mu_{s-1}}^{\alpha_{s-1}\dot{\alpha}_{s-1}}\,\omega_{\mu_s|\alpha_1...\alpha_{s-1},\dot{\alpha}_1...\dot{\alpha}_{s-1}}\sim \Phi_{\mu_1...\mu_s}</math> :where the symmetrization on the left is implied; * The <math>\omega</math>-equation can be shown to impose the Fronsdal equations for s=2,3,4,... . The Maxwell equations and the Klein-Gordon equations for the s=1 and s=0 components of the multiplet are in the C-equation; * Other components are expressed as on-shell derivatives of the Fronsdal field; * The order-s derivative of the Fronsdal field with the symmetry of the higher-spin Weyl tensor determines the corresponding component of the C-field via the right-hand side of the <math>\omega</math>-equation.
To conclude, anti-de Sitter space is an exact solution of the Vasiliev equations and upon linearization over it one finds unfolded equations that are equivalent to the Fronsdal equations for fields with s=0,1,2,3,... .
== Other dimensions, extensions, and generalisations ==
* there is an important option to introduce a free parameter in the four-dimensional equations, which is related to the parity breaking. The only modifications needed are :<math> \begin{array}{ll} \left[S_{{\alpha}},S_{{\beta}}\right]=-2i\epsilon_{\alpha\beta} (1+e^{i\theta}B\star \varkappa) & \left[S_{\dot{\alpha}},S_{\dot{\beta}}\right]=-2i\epsilon_{\dot{\alpha}\dot{\beta}}(1+e^{-i\theta} B\star \bar{\varkappa}) \end{array}</math> :This free parameter plays in important role in the [[Higher-spin theory#Higher Spin AdS/CFT Correspondence|higher-spin AdS/CFT correspondence]]. The theory at <math>\theta=0,\pi/2</math> is parity invariant; :One can also take <math>\theta</math> to be any even function <math>\theta(x)=\theta(-x)</math> of <math>B\star \varkappa</math> in the first equation above and of <math>B\star \bar{\varkappa}</math> in the second one, which does not destroy the consistency of the equations.
* one can introduce Yang-Mills groups<ref name=superHS>{{cite journal|last1=Konstein|first1=S.E.|last2=Vasiliev|first2=M.A.|title=Extended higher-spin superalgebras and their massless representations|journal=Nuclear Physics B|date=February 1990|volume=331|issue=2|pages=475–499|doi=10.1016/0550-3213(90)90216-Z|bibcode=1990NuPhB.331..475K}}</ref> by letting the fields take values in the tensor product of the Y-Z algebra with the matrix algebra and then imposing truncations as to get <math>o(N),u(N), usp(N)</math>; * the four-dimensional equations reviewed above can be extended with super-symmetries.<ref name=superHS/> One needs to extend the Y-Z algebra with additional Clifford-like elements :<math>\left\{\xi_i,\xi_j\right\}=2\delta_{ij}</math> so that the fields are now function of <math>Y,Z,\xi</math> and space-time coordinates. The components of the fields are required to have the right spin-statistic. The equations need to be slightly modified.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Sezgin|first1=Ergin|last2=Sundell|first2=Per|title=Supersymmetric higher spin theories|journal=Journal of Physics A: Mathematical and Theoretical|date=31 May 2013|volume=46|issue=21|pages=214022|doi=10.1088/1751-8113/46/21/214022|arxiv=1208.6019|bibcode=2013JPhA...46u4022S}}</ref>
There also exist Vasiliev's equations in other dimensions: * in three dimensions there is the minimal higher-spin theory<ref name=VasThree/> and its development, known as Prokushkin-Vasiliev theory,<ref name=VasProk/> that is based on a one-parameter family of higher-spin algebras (usually the family is denoted as <math>hs(\lambda)</math>) and also allows for super-symmetric extensions; * there exist Vasiliev equations that operate in any space-time dimension.<ref name=VasD/> The spectrum of the theory consists of all the fields with integer (or even only) spins. The equations are very similar to the four-dimensional ones, but there are some important modifications in the definition of the algebra that the fields take values in and there are further constraints in the d-dimensional case.
== Discrepancies between Vasiliev equations and Higher Spin Theories == There is a number of flaws/features of the Vasiliev equations that have been revealed over the last years. First of all, classical equations of motion, e.g. the Vasiliev equations, do not allow one to address the problems that require an action, the most basic one being quantization. Secondly, there are discrepancies between the results obtained from the Vasiliev equations and those from the other formulations of higher spin theories, from the [[AdS/CFT correspondence]] or from general field theory perspective. Most of the discrepancies can be attributed to the assumptions used in the derivation of the equations: gauge invariance is manifest, but locality was not properly imposed and the Vasiliev equations are a solution of a certain formal deformation problem. Practically speaking, it is not known in general how to extract the interaction vertices of the higher spin theory out of the equations.
Most of the studies concern with the four-dimensional Vasiliev equations. The correction to the free spin-2 equations due to the scalar field stress-tensor was extracted out of the four-dimensional Vasiliev equations and found to be<ref name=Krist>{{Cite journal|last=Kristiansson|first=Fredric|last2=Rajan|first2=Peter|date=2003|title=Scalar field corrections to AdS 4 gravity from higher spin gauge theory|url=http://stacks.iop.org/1126-6708/2003/i=04/a=009|journal=Journal of High Energy Physics|language=en|volume=2003|issue=04|pages=009|doi=10.1088/1126-6708/2003/04/009|issn=1126-6708}}</ref> :<math> G_{\mu\nu}+\Lambda g_{\mu\nu}= Re(b_1^2)\left[ \sum_k \left( \xi_k g_{\mu\nu} \nabla_{\rho(k+1)}\phi \nabla^{\rho(k+1)}\phi + \eta_k \nabla_{\mu\rho(k)}\phi \nabla^{\rho(k)}{}_{\nu}\phi+\zeta_k\nabla_{\mu\nu\rho(k)}\phi \nabla^{\rho(k)}\phi\right)-\frac49 g_{\mu\nu} \phi^2\right] </math> where <math display="inline">\nabla_{\rho(k)}\phi = '\nabla_{\rho_1}...\nabla_{\rho_k}\phi +\text{symmetrization}-\text{traces}'</math> are symmetrized derivatives with traces subtracted. The most important information is in the coefficients <math display="inline">\xi_k, \eta_k, \zeta_k</math> and in the prefactor <math display="inline">Re(b_1^2)</math>, where <math display="inline">b_1=\exp[i\theta]</math> is a free parameter that the equations have, see [[Vasiliev equations#Other dimensions, extensions, and generalisations|Other dimensions, extensions, and generalisations]]. It is important to note that the usual stress-tensor has no more than two derivative and the terms <math>k>0</math> are not independent (for example, they contribute to the same <math display="inline">\langle T_{ab} j_0j_0\rangle</math> AdS/CFT three-point function). This is a general property of field theories that one can perform nonlinear (and also higher derivative) field redefinitions and therefore there exist infinitely many ways to write the same interaction vertex at the classical level. The canonical stress-tensor has two derivatives and the terms with contracted derivatives can be related to it via such redefinitions.
A surprising fact that had been noticed<ref name=Krist/><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Sezgin |first1=Ergin |last2=Sundell |first2=Pear |title=Holography in 4D (super) higher spin theories and a test via cubic scalar couplings |journal=Journal of High Energy Physics |date=19 July 2005 |volume=2005 |issue=07 |pages=044–044 |doi=10.1088/1126-6708/2005/07/044}}</ref> before its inconsistency with the AdS/CFT was realized is that the stress-tensor can change sign and, in particular, vanishes for <math display="inline">\theta=\pi/4</math>. This would imply that the corresponding correlation function in the Chern-Simons matter theories vanishes, <math display="inline">\langle T_{ab} j_0j_0\rangle=0</math>, which is not the case.
The most important and detailed tests were performed much later. It was first shown<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Giombi |first1=Simone |last2=Yin |first2=Xi |title=Higher spin gauge theory and holography: the three-point functions |journal=Journal of High Energy Physics |date=30 September 2010 |volume=2010 |issue=9 |doi=10.1007/JHEP09(2010)115}}</ref> that some of the three-point AdS/CFT functions, as obtained from the Vasiliev equations, turn out to be infinite or inconsistent with AdS/CFT, while some other do agree. Those that agree, in the language of [[Vasiliev equations#Unfolded equations|Unfolded equations]] correspond to <math>\omega\star C-C\star \pi(\omega)</math> and the infinities/inconsistencies resulted from <math>\mathcal{V}(\omega,C,C)</math>. The terms of the first type are local and are fixed by the higher spin algebra. The terms of the second type can be non-local (when solved perturbatively the master field <math>C</math> is a generating functions of infinitely many derivatives of higher spin fields). These non-localities are not present in higher spin theories as can be seen from the explicit cubic action<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Sleight |first1=Charlotte |last2=Taronna |first2=Massimo |title=Higher Spin Interactions from Conformal Field Theory: The Complete Cubic Couplings |journal=Physical Review Letters |date=2 May 2016 |volume=116 |issue=18 |doi=10.1103/PhysRevLett.116.181602}}</ref>.
Further infinities, non-localities or missing structures were observed<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Giombi |first1=Simone |last2=Yin |first2=Xi |title=Higher spins in AdS and twistorial holography |journal=Journal of High Energy Physics |date=18 April 2011 |volume=2011 |issue=4 |doi=10.1007/JHEP04(2011)086}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Giombi |first1=Simone |last2=Yin |first2=Xi |title=Higher spin gauge theory and the critical model |journal=Physical Review D |date=18 April 2012 |volume=85 |issue=8 |doi=10.1103/PhysRevD.85.086005}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Giombi |first1=Simone |last2=Minwalla |first2=Shiraz |last3=Prakash |first3=Shiroman |last4=Trivedi |first4=Sandip P. |last5=Wadia |first5=Spenta R. |last6=Yin |first6=Xi |title=Chern–Simons theory with vector fermion matter |journal=The European Physical Journal C |date=25 August 2012 |volume=72 |issue=8 |doi=10.1140/epjc/s10052-012-2112-0}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Giombi |first1=Simone |last2=Yin |first2=Xi |title=The higher spin/vector model duality |journal=Journal of Physics A: Mathematical and Theoretical |date=31 May 2013 |volume=46 |issue=21 |pages=214003 |doi=10.1088/1751-8113/46/21/214003}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Chang |first1=Chi-Ming |last2=Minwalla |first2=Shiraz |last3=Sharma |first3=Tarun |last4=Yin |first4=Xi |title=ABJ triality: from higher spin fields to strings |journal=Journal of Physics A: Mathematical and Theoretical |date=31 May 2013 |volume=46 |issue=21 |pages=214009 |doi=10.1088/1751-8113/46/21/214009}}</ref>. Some of these tests explore the extension of the [[Higher-spin theory#Klebanov-Polyakov Conjecture|Klebanov-Polyakov Conjecture]] to Chern-Simons matter theories where the structure of correlation functions is more intricate and certain parity-odd terms are present. Some of these structures were not reproduced by the Vasiliev equations. General analysis of the Vasiliev equations at the second order<ref name=Bref/> showed that for any three fixed spins the interaction term is an infinite series in derivatives (similar to <math>k</math>-sum above); all of the terms in the series contribute to the same AdS/CFT three-point function and the contribution is infinite. All the problems can be attributed to the assumptions used in the derivation of the Vasiliev equations: restrictions on the number of derivatives in the interaction vertices or, more generally, locality was not imposed, which is important for getting meaningful interaction vertices, see e.g. [[Higher-spin theory#Noether Procedure|Noether Procedure]]. The problem how to impose locality and extract interaction vertices out of the equations is now under active investigation<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Vasiliev |first1=M.A. |title=Current interactions and holography from the 0-form sector of nonlinear higher-spin equations |journal=Journal of High Energy Physics |date=17 October 2017 |volume=2017 |issue=10 |doi=10.1007/JHEP10(2017)111}}</ref>.
As is briefly mentioned in [[Vasiliev equations#Other dimensions, extensions, and generalisations|Other dimensions, extensions, and generalisations]] there is an option to introduce infinitely many additional coupling constants that enter via phase factor <math>\theta(x)=\theta_0 +\theta_2 x^2+...</math>. As was noted<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Maldacena |first1=Juan |last2=Zhiboedov |first2=Alexander |title=Constraining conformal field theories with a slightly broken higher spin symmetry |journal=Classical and Quantum Gravity |date=21 May 2013 |volume=30 |issue=10 |pages=104003 |doi=10.1088/0264-9381/30/10/104003}}</ref>, the second such coefficient <math>\theta_2</math> will affect five-point AdS/CFT correlation functions, but not the three-point ones, which seems to be in tension with the results obtained directly from imposing higher spin symmetry on the correlation functions. Later, it was shown<ref name=Bref>{{cite journal |last1=Boulanger |first1=Nicolas |last2=Kessel |first2=Pan |last3=Skvortsov |first3=Evgeny |last4=Taronna |first4=Massimo |title=Higher spin interactions in four-dimensions: Vasiliev versus Fronsdal |journal=Journal of Physics A: Mathematical and Theoretical |date=4 March 2016 |volume=49 |issue=9 |pages=095402 |doi=10.1088/1751-8113/49/9/095402}}</ref> that the terms in the equations that result from <math>\theta_{2,4,...}</math> are too non-local and lead to an infinite result for the AdS/CFT correlation functions.
In three dimensions the Prokushkin-Vasiliev equations, which are supposed to describe interactions of matter fields with higher spin fields in three dimensions, are also affected by the aforementioned locality problem. For example, the perturbative corrections at the second order to the stress-tensors of the matter fields lead to infinite correlation functions<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Skvortsov |first1=Evgeny |last2=Taronna |first2=Massimo |title=On locality, holography and unfolding |journal=Journal of High Energy Physics |date=6 November 2015 |volume=2015 |issue=11 |doi=10.1007/JHEP11(2015)044}}</ref>. There is, however, another discrepancy: the spectrum of the Prokushkin-Vasiliev equations has, in addition to the matter fields (scalar and spinor) and higher spin fields, a set of unphysical fields that do not have any field theory interpretation, but interact with the physical fields.
== Exact solutions ==
Since the Vasiliev equations are quite complicated there are few exact solutions known * as it was already shown, there is an important solution --- empty anti-de Sitter space, whose existence allows to interpret the linearized fluctuations as massless fields of all spins; * in three dimensions to find anti-de Sitter space as an exact solution for all values of the parameter <math>\lambda</math> turns out to be a nontrivial problem, but it is known;<ref name=VasProk/> * there is a domain-wall type solution of the four-dimensional equations;<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Sezgin|first1=E.|last2=Sundell|first2=P.|title=An exact solution of 4D higher-spin gauge theory|journal=Nuclear Physics B|date=January 2007|volume=762|issue=1–2|pages=1–37|doi=10.1016/j.nuclphysb.2006.06.038|arxiv=hep-th/0508158|bibcode=2007NuPhB.762....1S}}</ref> * there is a family of the solutions to the four-dimensional equations that are interpreted as black holes, although the metric transforms under the higher-spin transformations and for that reason it is difficult to rely on the usual definition of the horizon etc.;<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Didenko|first1=V.E.|last2=Vasiliev|first2=M.A.|title=Static BPS black hole in 4d higher-spin gauge theory|journal=Physics Letters B|date=December 2009|volume=682|issue=3|pages=305–315|doi=10.1016/j.physletb.2009.11.023|bibcode=2009PhLB..682..305D|arxiv=0906.3898}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Iazeolla|first1=Carlo|last2=Sundell|first2=Per|title=Families of exact solutions to Vasiliev's 4D equations with spherical, cylindrical and biaxial symmetry|journal=Journal of High Energy Physics|date=22 December 2011|volume=2011|issue=12|doi=10.1007/JHEP12(2011)084|arxiv=1107.1217|bibcode=2011JHEP...12..084I}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Bourdier|first1=Jun|last2=Drukker|first2=Nadav|title=On classical solutions of 4d supersymmetric higher spin theory|journal=Journal of High Energy Physics|date=20 April 2015|volume=2015|issue=4|doi=10.1007/JHEP04(2015)097|arxiv=1411.7037|bibcode=2015JHEP...04..097B}}</ref> * in the case of three-dimensions there is a consistent truncation that decouples the scalar field from the higher-spin fields, the latter being described by the Chern–Simons theory. In this case any flat connection of the higher-spin algebra is an exact solution and there has been a lot of works on this subclass;
